EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR DOWNIE,
dated May 30th, 1927, on his inspection
of the Mud Lake Indian Day School.

Original on File 25-1-6.

"The present school building, the Community
Hall, a church and two closets complete the property.
The buildings are in a good state of repair, except
that the closets are in an unsanitary condition."

"Two rooms have been fitted up in what was
formerly known as the Community Hall and the former
school building now serves as a Community Hall. Miss
Lewis has the greater number of pupils and her class-
room is the smaller. A re-adjustment of the number
of pupils in each room might prove beneficial."

"Note--- The Hall, used as the school, is heated by a
furnace."
Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mud Lake Indian Day School, states that the closets are in an unsanitary condition. I have to request that you will arrange to have these closets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition during the coming summer holidays. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred.

Please forward a voucher, in duplicate, properly certified, in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

V. M. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterborough, Ont.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR DOWNEY,
dated September 26th, 1927, on his inspection of the Mud Lake Indian Day School.

Original on File 25-1-6.

Paper towels, a mirror for each room and some sort of cupboard in the junior room are needed. The junior room should have a clock.

The closets need attention before winter sets in.
Ottawa, October 20, 1927.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mud Lake Indian Day School, recommends that a mirror be supplied for each room, also that a cupboard and clock should be provided for the junior room.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery to the school of two mirrors of an inexpensive type, and an alarm clock of the Big Ben type for the junior room.

Relative to the cupboard, I shall be pleased if you will state whether you could have a suitable cupboard built locally, or whether you would recommend that same be purchased. In either event, you should state the approximate cost of supplying a cupboard that would be suitable for the purpose for which it is required.

The Inspector also states that the closets require attention before winter sets in. You will be good enough to see that these closets are thoroughly cleaned out and placed in a good state of repair at an early date. No unnecessary expense should be incurred.

Please forward a properly certified voucher, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the above authorized supplies and for any work performed on the closets.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

V. M. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterboro, Ont.

Ottawa, January 17, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letters of the 12th instant, enclosing a voucher in payment of two boxes of chalk for the use of the Mud Lake Indian Day School, and requesting authority to purchase other classroom supplies.

In reply I have to inform you that all classroom material is supplied to Indian day schools through the Government Stationery Office here. The teacher should prepare, in due time, a requisition for his requirements, and this he should hand to you, and you should certify and send same to the Department. If the teacher would anticipate his requirements and prepare a requisition on the form for that purpose in due time there would be an ample supply of classroom material on hand. In future, the Department cannot pay accounts covering the cost of materials of this nature supplied the school, and you should inform the teacher accordingly. The account which you forwarded in payment of two boxes of chalk will be paid.

We have placed an order with the Stationery Office here to send to the teacher's address a quantity of chalk, blackboard erasers, pens, pen handles, ink powder and exercise books. Should he require any further supplies, he should immediately requisition for same through your office.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

V. M. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterborough, Ont.

Sir:

Attached is account from Trebilcock Brothers, Peterborough, for foolscap which the teacher at Mud Lake Reserve urgently required for his work.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Mud and Rice Lake Reserves.
Ottawa, October 23, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing an account covering the cost of three reams of foolscap supplied for the use of the Mud Lake Indian Day School.

In this connection I would refer you to official letter of January 17, 1928, informing you that all classroom material is supplied to Indian day schools through the Government Stationery Office here, upon receipt of a requisition from the teacher for his requirements. In that letter, you were also informed that the Department cannot pay accounts for classroom materials ordered by the teacher. The teacher should anticipate his wants and prepare a requisition for the classroom supplies required by him. This, he should forward through your office, when the materials will be sent from the Government Stationery Office. It is considered that the quantity ordered - three reams, or 1500 sheets, of paper - is excessive, also the price charged, viz., $3 per ream, is very high. I may say, for your information, that the Stationery Office supplies foolscap at a cost of $1.45 per ream.

Until we have a full explanation regarding the purchase of this paper, the Department is not prepared to pay the account. A supply of requisition forms is enclosed herewith. Please hand these to the teacher, in order that he can make application to the Department for the supplies required by him, in due time.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

V. McC. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterborough, Ont.
EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR DONNEY,
dated October 9th, 1928, on his inspection of the MUD LAKE Indian Day School.

Original on File 25-1-6.

The property is in a reasonably good state of repair except that the unsanitary condition of the closets continues to furnish a problem.
Ottawa, October 26, 1928.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mud Lake Indian Day School, states that the closets are in an unsanitary condition and continue to furnish a problem.

I have to request that you will arrange to have these closets thoroughly cleaned out and placed in a good, sanitary condition. If any repairs are required, you should have same made. You should keep all costs in this connection as low as possible. Please have this work completed before the extreme cold weather sets in. An account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

V. McC. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterborough,
Ont.
THE SECRETARY,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir: Reference your letter #25-1-5, October 23/28.

In explanation regarding the purchase of foolscap for the teacher at Mud Lake Reserve, I wish to state that he ran short and needed this material immediately for examination paper for the last quarter and did not realize his supplies were so low until the day before the writing of his tests.

In regard to the price of Three Dollars per ream this is the price quoted at both the stationery stores in this city and the only place it could be obtained.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Mud and Rice Lake Reserves.
Ottawa, October 30, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th instant, regarding the purchase by the teacher of the Mud Lake Indian Day School of 3 reams of foolscap.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will pay this account as an emergency purchase, but I would again point out, as previously stated in official letters of January 17th, 1926, and the 23rd instant, that the Department cannot, in future, pay accounts for classroom materials ordered by the teacher. It is necessary, according to regulations, that supplies of this nature be obtained through the Government Stationery Office here. The teacher should anticipate his requirements and prepare a requisition for any supplies required. This he should forward to the Department through your office. It is noted that he required the foolscap for use as examination paper, but it is not understood why it was necessary for him to purchase such a large quantity.

I enclose a copy of this letter which you should hand to the teacher for his future guidance.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

V. McC. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterborough,
Ont.

THE SECRETARY,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir:

The wood burning stove which supplies heat to the school rooms at Mud Lake day school has burned out and is beyond repair. Temporary measures have been taken to provide heat but these are not satisfactory as the stove fills the school room with smoke. It will be necessary for us to purchase a new one.

I have asked several heating concerns here for prices but as yet have not received them. In the meanwhile I am writing you for authority to make a purchase. I have had two heating men up at the Reserve and they claim the stove is beyond repair. This stove is from 20 to 25 years old. The same condition applies to the church, although not quite so urgent.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Mud and Rice Lake Reserves.
Ottawa, March 2nd, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, reporting on the condition of the stove at present in use to heat the classrooms at the Mud Lake Indian Day School, and requesting that you be given authority to purchase a new one. It is noted that the present stove is beyond repair.

You may arrange for the purchase and installation of a new stove of a type that would be satisfactory to heat this school. If possible you should obtain competitive prices and make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. If any new stove pipe is required, you may also purchase same. After this stove has been supplied, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. The purchase and installation of this stove should receive your early attention.

Relative to the condition of the stove in the church, you should draw this matter to the attention of the Department at an early date, giving full particulars as to the type and cost of the stove which you would recommend be supplied.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

V. M. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterborough, Ont.

Ottawa, June 28th, 1929.

Sir:

A coat of paint on the floor of the Senior room and the woodwork throughout the whole interior repainted would make a much cleaner and brighter school. Many of the window panes need putty and the sash, window and door frames are in need of a coat of paint.

Sir,

The matter of purchasing a stove for use at the Mud Lake Reserve Day School, and the repairing of the one in the church, I beg to say that I have had experts look over both furnaces, and it has been stated by all that they are beyond repair and out of date.

The one in the church was found to be in very bad condition. I have made inquiries at the Reserve as to their supply of body wood for heating purposes and find that this is very limited, coal being practically as cheap. I had two local firms draw up costs for installing new furnaces both in the school and church. The one most reasonable has been described as follows.

For furnishing and installing two No. 10-24 Pilot Success Pipe Furnaces at Curve Lake church and school, Five Hundred and Ninety-eight dollars. Both furnaces will have a heating capacity of forty thousand cubic feet, and will be equipped with fire grates to burn either coal or wood. This tender was supplied by Archibald and Richmond, plumbers of Peterborough.

All parties consulted informed me that present equipment would be impossible to repair for permanent satisfaction. It has been rather difficult to get local plumbers to supply a quotation during this busy season and hence the reason for delay, but as furnaces have been not urgently required I trust that September and October would be adequate time to install this equipment.
You authorized me to purchase the equipment but as the cost is as high as it is, I thought best to inform you.

I am attaching a resolution covering the matter of repair of the furnace for the church passed at a regular session of band council.

Your obedient servant,

Sir: Reference your letter #25-1-5, September 12/29.

I beg to say that your understanding that the present stoves in the school and church were wood-burning stoves is correct, although they were built-in bricked installations about the dimensions of a furnace. In the school there are three registers taken off to heat the various rooms. The only thing that could be done would be to install furnaces.

As to the present equipment, it is so obsolete and out of date and in such poor repair, that anything done in the nature of repairing would be only temporary. In regard to securing additional quotations, I will do this immediately and quote them on a separate basis for the church and school.

Sir:

The Indian Day school at Mud Lake was closed to allow the teachers to attend a Teachers' Convention at Peterboro. I examined the building which was originally built for a Community Hall and is not altogether suitable for a school. These Indians are clamouring for a new Council Hall, but if any building is anticipated, it should be a new two class School, and the present structure turned over to be used as a Council Hall. Before leaving on my inspectional trip, I was instructed to examine the school furnace. I found it entirely useless, and dangerous to the building. It has been in use for twenty-five or thirty years. A new furnace is being installed at the present time. The Agent informs me that both teachers are giving very good service and that the pupils are making steady progress. A Long Fire Travel—Another Sense for the Pease "Economy"

When this picture was taken the camera was looking down on the top of an uncased Pease "Economy" Furnace and it explains the fire travel very clearly. You will notice that the hot gases strike the top of the combustion chamber and then pass through the flue pipe (two of them "double hoods"), making the top of the furnace very hot with the seat radiator around both sides of the Pease Heat Radiator. The fire travels until it reaches the smoke collar at the rear. By this time there is very little heat left to pass up the chimney. The cold air supply is connected to the bottom of the galvanized iron casing that encloses the Pease furnace, and the cold air heated by passing over the hot sides of the casing, enters the combustion chamber and radiator. It leaves the furnace through the opening just taken from the top of the casing and passes to the upstairs rooms. One item we must keep in mind is that practically all heat waste is eliminated with a Pease "Economy" Furnace. It is so constructed that you get every bit of heat that it is possible to extract from the fire.

Pease
Pease Combination Coils

The Pease Combination Heating System is simple and comprehensive. By an effective arrangement of coils and air-heating surface, the apparatus is able to warm and distribute air, and WITH THE SAME FIRE, to promote a circulation of hot water.

The Pease Combination Coils illustrated on this page are placed in the combustion chamber directly over the fire, thereby MAKING DOUBLY USEFUL a large portion of heat energy which would otherwise be used only in heating air. When Pease Combination Heating Systems are in service, the cold air is warmed by passing over the heating surfaces of the furnace in the usual way, is moistened by evaporation from the water pan, and is distributed to the rooms above through warm air pipes and registers. These registers are placed in the rooms nearest the furnace, while the exposed and more distant rooms are heated by hot water radiators. Thus a method of ventilation is assured.

Pease Combination Coils are made in sixteen sizes, rated to carry from 80 to 570 square feet of direct hot water radiation in addition to that of the mains. These sixteen sizes are interchangeable so that the castings may be assembled in any particular form that may be necessary, the total number of variations being very large.
Another Dollar Saver—
The Pease Air Blast

At the back of and just above the firepot is an ingenious device whereby a strong current of hot air enters the combustion chamber and mixes with the gases generated by the fire, insuring complete combustion. This is the Pease Air Blast. It has a sloping hood over the outlets to prevent its becoming clogged with ashes or coal-dust and is connected to an opening in the outer casing.

Explained in a simple manner this means that you burn a certain amount of air which costs you nothing. Another strong argument in its favor is that the Pease Air Blast enables you to burn soft coal as fuel.

At the present time there are innumerable appliances called "gas blasts," "Carburetors," etc., being offered for use with furnaces, but the Pease stands alone as being the introducer of this fuel saver in Canada. It has formed part of our regular equipment for many years and is one of the main reasons why the Pease "Economy" is looked upon as a most efficient heating outfit.

The tank may be in the basement or upstairs, whichever is most convenient to the user.

This One-Piece Ashpit Eliminates the Dust Nuisance

How often have you heard people complain about the dust that comes from a poorly constructed furnace? And maybe in your own mind you have condemned all furnaces for this reason, little thinking that in the Pease "Economy" a simple idea has been perfected that overcomes this trouble.

In most furnaces the ashpit is moulded in several sections and bolted together. This is a cheaper way of manufacturing, but it leaves joints through which ashes and dust can escape into the air chamber and then to the rooms above. MEMO FOR FILE:

Mr. Indian Agent Eastwood and Chief Whetung visited the Department today and discussed the need for a new school at Mud Lake. Two classrooms are required. A central site on the public part of the reserve can be secured immediately to the west of the church, where there is at present an old frame building on a stone foundation. Dear Sir,

At a regular monthly council meeting of the Mississaugas of Mud Lake Band held at the Council Hall on Friday, December 7, 1934, the following resolution was moved by Councillor James McCue. Seconded by Councillor Albert Whiting and carried:

As the present school class rooms are held in our Council Hall, which is unsuitable in every way for this purpose and there is not sufficient accommodation for the number of pupils attending schools, we request the department at Ottawa to grant us a proper school for this reserve and return to us our Council Hall for the purpose it was originally intended.

George Coppaway, Secy.
Peterborough, Jan. 17, 1935.

The Secretary,

Sir:

I enclose a resolution passed at a regular meeting of the Mud Lake Band Council held at the Council Hall on the Reserve on the 17th of December last.

The building referred to in the resolution is a two-story, three-roomed brick building originally built as a Town Hall or Council Hall. It has been used for some years for a school. At the present time there are 63 pupils attending school on the reserve. Mr. Rome conducts the senior classroom on the ground floor, with an attendance of 26 pupils. Miss Long has a junior class with 37 pupils on the second floor. The building not being designed in the first place for a school, has a great many disadvantages. The classroom downstairs has no room for additional desks. At the present time it is crowded with every foot of space used. The lighting is very poor and in the winter months it is difficult for the children to see the blackboards after two o'clock.

The junior class on the second floor has just sufficient room. The lighting is from three sides and, although much better than the senior classroom in this regard, there are cross lights which are difficult to overcome. About four years ago a new heating furnace was put in this building. This has been working out very satisfactorily. The whole building needs considerable repairs. Several large cracks have appeared in the walls within the last year and, although not endangering the building, will have to be looked after when the weather permits in the spring. The whole building requires painting inside and out.

The building is not suitable for the purpose it is now used for, and for some time now the old church has been used for a Council Hall and Community Hall. This has been dilapidated for years and not worth the expense of repairs. It is near to the point of not being able to be used for any purpose. This possibly is one of the reasons for the resolution requesting the return of the hall as a Council Hall.
The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

About four years ago there was an estimate in the annual appropriation to cover the cost of a new school at this reserve. This was cut along with other things during the past difficult years. I went into the matter very thoroughly with Mr. Ferrier at that time and this may be on record.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Mud & Rice Lakes Agency.

Sir:

Re Mud Lake Day School.

I have instructed Mr. Rose to carry out fire drills as a precautionary measure at the school. Of necessity the junior classroom is on the second floor which leaves the sill of the windows about 25 feet from the ground. There is only one stairway down from the second floor and this stairway is in a well, with the cellar stair going down underneath, and the ceiling going up to the small bell tower. The upstairs classrooms and the downstairs rooms open into this hallway or well.

With the small children on the second floor, I would suggest that some other means of getting down should be considered. I think a ladder to reach the second floor windows should be kept near the building or an iron fire escape should be considered. I would suggest that a medium sized fire extinguisher be placed at the main entrance and this be put in charge of the caretaker.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a resolution passed at the regular meeting of the Mud Lake Band in Council, on the 17th ultimo, requesting that the use of the council hall for school purposes be discontinued and that a new school building be erected.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will have no funds during the coming fiscal year, 1935-36, to provide the cost of erecting a two-roomed school for the Indian children on the Mud Lake reserve, and it will therefore be necessary to continue the use of the council hall. The need for a new school building will not be lost sight of, but its erection will depend upon Parliament providing funds for the purpose. The Department regrets any inconvenience caused the Council in having to use the old church as a council and community hall.

With reference to the matter of fire hazard in the exit by the stairway from the junior classroom on the second floor, used for school purposes, there would, no doubt, be certain danger if fire occurred, as the stairway might act as a flue in drawing the smoke and flames. I would request that you state if you would recommend the building of an outside covered stairway, with a door installed, leading into the classroom, and closing up or removing the present stairway. If so, please submit an estimate of the cost of erecting an inexpensive stairway, supported by stout cement piers. If the expenditure would not involve a large amount, favourable consideration might be given to the erection of the outside stairway and discontinuing the use of the inside stairs. The cost of the erection of a properly constructed iron fire escape would not be much less than the building of the outside stairway. In winter, if the escape was covered with snow and ice, it would be dangerous for younger pupils. As this building will be required for school purposes for a considerable period, it will be necessary to take precautions for the safety of the children, in case of fire. You should see that the janitor is careful in keeping the furnace room clean and that no rubbish is allowed near the furnace.

Upon the occasion of your next visit, you should make a thorough inspection of the furnace room at this school. When the Department has your views regarding the building of the outside stairway and the cost involved, consideration will be given to the question of whether the work can be authorized.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Sir:-

Re: Mud Lake Day School

I inclose a resolution of the Mud Lake Band Council suggesting certain changes in the above school.

In my letter of January 17th, 1935 I explained the inadequate accommodations of the present building in use as a school.

Mr. Reme expects an addition in attendance for the fall term and additional desks will be required, and no room available for their placing.

At the last council meeting I explained this to the Council and asked them their views on allowing the present council room to be included in the senior class room which is on the main floor, and where the situation is more acute.

I attach a rough sketch of the ground floor plan of the School. The partition is not a supporting wall. The joints are three by sixteen and run as shown in the sketch. The partition is only lath and plaster. I would recommend this.

For a Council Hall, the Council propose to use the old building to the south of the church which has been used for community purposes.

In the last paragraph of the resolution there is a recommendation that the brick walls be repaired. This should be done this year. There are several large cracks and the cellar window openings require attention. The arches above these openings have been knocked out by being passed into the cellar.

New roofing is required. The shingles have been on since the building was erected some thirty-five years ago. The whole building requires painting.

This seems a large order but I think the whole thing can be done reasonably. I suggest that estimates be secured from contractors, to include the concrete steps. BUILDING REQUIREMENTS: ROOMS AND ACCOMMODATION; NUMBER OF PUPILS; TYPE OF CONSTRUCTION.  
Two classrooms about 33 x 24 in size, with southern exposure, to supply accommodation for present future requirements—possibly 50 to 100 pupils during life of building. Normal attendance is 60 pupils with two teachers. Building could be one story with basement for heating equipment, fuel, and toilets. Foundation cement and building of brick. Teacher's residence is not required.  

DESCRIPTION OF SITE AND CONDITIONS; SUBMIT PLAN; NORTH POINT; NATURE OF SOIL, DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS AND ANY OTHER PARTICULARS.  
The site suggested and shown in plan is 150' from lake shore with a gradual slope to water edge, providing good drainage. The soil appears to be loam on gravel and there would be no excavation difficulties as the limestone rock already does not occur here. The elevation is about 20' above lake. The plot of ground owned by the Band and the dimensions are as shown on plan. Any ground space is provided by the balance of the survey.  

WATER SUPPLY: SYSTEM REQUIRED; SOURCE OF WATER, ETC.  
By force pump to reservoir from lake for toilets & washrooms. Drinking water from well which could be located anywhere near site.

TOILET FACILITIES: SEWAGE DISPOSAL; SYSTEM REQUIRED; LOCATION.

Water toilets could be supplied from reservoir in building with water pumped from lake by gasoline when power available by electric pump. Septic tank for sewage disposal. Site proposed for this 150 feet back from lake with a lift of about 20'.

HEATING SYSTEM: TYPE OF FURNACE OR BOILER; FUEL.

Hot air heating system with air conditioning equipment. Water would be difficult to use unless intake from lake was buried below first floor. Gas would be available if proposed building additional cost. Costliness is about $750.00.

LIGHTING SYSTEM: SOURCE OF POWER; SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS.

At the present time, the nearest source of power is the Ontario Hydro line to Buckhorn, about 3½ miles distant.

Power will eventually be available. Building should be wired.

BUILT-IN EQUIPMENT REQUIRED: BLACKBOARD AREA; CUPBOARDS, ETC.

Each class room to have space end with half partition for cloak rooms. Class rooms were 38' x 24' which would accommodate about 40 to 50 pupils each, the two wall surfaces with blackboards at eye level, approximately about 4' high.

SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS FOR MATERIALS: NEAREST SHIPPING POINT.

LOCAL TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES TO SITE, ETC.

By Canadian National Railway to Lakefield, Ontario. Then by truck 13 miles to Mud Lake Reserve.

REMARKS:

Reservoir tank or well or built into roof could be utilized for additional fire protection. There is no fire protection by the system. Suggested site is away from the road. Recent building used as school is in a noisy location close to traffic through the Village.

Dear Sir,

As directed in your letter 25-1-5 of December 16th I have completed the building data form to the best of my ability. I also enclose tracing showing the proposed site. The property outlined in the plan is the property of the Band. The plot of ground is rather irregular in shape and if there was not adequate space, additional property could be secured at reasonable cost from Band members. The suggested site is as near to the centre of population on the Reserve as will permit the use of water for toilets, etc. The shoreline is very attractive and gradually shoals out to the channel on Buckhorn lake which passes the Reserve opposite this location.

At the present time there are about sixty pupils of school age. The present outlook is that there should be a steady increase in the numbers. In 1898 there were 163 members in this Band according to the pay-list; in 1928 - 284; in 1938 - 326. There has been a steady increase in the last few years. Considering the next twenty years requirements, accommodation for one hundred pupils should be provided.
Accommodation for the teachers in charge of the Mud Lake School is reasonably well provided for at the present time. Chief D. E. Whetung boards them at reasonable rates at his place, a short distance from the school. Should the senior teacher require a separate dwelling the "Mission House" could be made available. I have discussed the matter with the two teachers and they seem to be satisfied with present arrangements.

The labour available at the Reserve is unskilled. I think it essential that the building be carried out by contract, with Indians employed where possible. There are three or four members of the Band who would work well as carpenters, two or three as painters. Excavations and rough forms could be completed by Indian labour.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 25-1-5 of Sept. 12th, with reference to the proposed well at the Mud Lake Indian Day School, I consider that a drilled well would be the more suitable as it would be completely closed in and be free from outside contamination and does not require the attention that a dug well would require from time to time, usually as a school well would not likely be used during the summer months and if a well is not used, it is more liable to accumulate silt and other foreign matter.

The usual type of well in this vicinity has been a dug well but most wells latterly have been driven. Arthur Whetung secured a loan last winter to have a well drilled on his property and it was necessary to go 60 feet to get an adequate supply. Comparing this with a dug well of 40 feet and the cost of each would be $210.00 for a driven well and $280.00 for a dug well. This driven well was in a more rocky formation than exists in the vicinity of the school and it would appear to me that it might be possible to secure water at a shallower depth. The school site is approximately 20 feet above the lake level but I am told this has not a great deal to do with the securing of water.
The Secretary,

In talking to the different well drillers I learn that water cannot be guaranteed at any depth but that 60 feet is a fairly deep well for this vicinity. I know of one well, which was drilled this summer which went down 55 feet, and this was at a 100 yards distance from the lake and about 20 feet above the lake.

In addition to the above costs there would be the cost of capping and the cost of a pump.

The only well driller I know of in the County is Melville Crowe of Warsaw Post Office, Peterborough County. His services would be available and his price is $3.50 per foot for a driven well. He uses 5" pipe and has dug a considerable number of successful wells in the County and elsewhere.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 25-1-5 of December 14th, the earliest advice I received that the seats were at Lakefield was at five o'clock Friday evening, December 8th and I went to Lakefield Saturday afternoon and arranged for the seats to be taken to the Mud Lake School first thing Monday morning, December 11th. The seats are now installed and it is expected the school will be occupied on Monday, December 18th.

I called the Canadian Pacific Railway on receipt of their Bill of Lading on December 4th and there was no word of the shipment at that time. I asked them to advise me when they were trans-shipped for Lakefield by Canadian National Railway. Not having heard any further word, I called Lakefield the morning of Wednesday, the 6th and was informed by the Station Master that the shipment had not arrived.

Dear Sir,-

RE: Mud Lake Indian Day School

The following articles are needed for cleaning and keeping the school in good order. The grounds around the building have been levelled off but the ground remains soft and will be muddy in mild weather. May I suggest that about four or five loads of crushed or screened gravel be spread around the approaches.

A mat will be required for the vestibule, which is the main entrance to the school as well as the basement, there being only one entrance to the building. The vestibule or porch has a floor area of 4'3" by 7'10". A cocoa mat suitable for the school may be obtained through Pratten Hardware, Peterborough, in two grades, Grade BE $21.00, Grade BG $24.00. This matting is made by the Cobourg Carpet and Matting Co., Cobourg, Ontario and the size of the mat quoted and recommended is 4'3" by 7'16". This allows clearance on the edges. Two mats could be purchased, one for each entrance, but I am afraid it would be difficult to keep them placed and there might be the danger of the children tripping on them. I also had in mind two boot scrapers but find these are not made but could be made up for $1.50 by a blacksmith.

The class room windows face south. The windows are 6'7" high and 3'15" wide inside the mouldings. These require window blinds about 3'9 or 10" wide and there are five such windows in each class room. They make a very bright class room but will require blinds to control the amount of sunlight.
The Secretary,

I request your permission to purchase cleaning tools for the care taker. I would suggest a push broom 16" wide for cleaning daily. These can be purchased for $2.50. The Board of Education at Peterborough purchases a better quality broom for $6.50. It might be that the cheaper broom would do on account of the lesser amount of work. Two mops will be required and two washing pails as well as cleaning materials.

May I have your authority to purchase locally the minimum supplies required.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

RE: Mud Lake Indian Day School

There has been considerable complaint about the odor emanating from the chemical lavatories in the new school. The caretaker says it is particularly strong when he opens up the school in the mornings after it has been closed all night and the teachers claim it is quite noticeable in the class rooms during the day.

I inspected the building and lavatories and I found there was a strong odor coming from these chemical closets. Instructions for their use have been followed closely by the caretaker and every means of keeping down the odor have been taken with no appreciable results. I called W. R. Turner of Peterborough, who made the installations and he said he would write the factory who made them and give me a reply but he was very doubtful whether any improvement could be made on this type of installation. The school has been in actual use for about a week so it is not a case of having them cleaned out.

I thought I would advise you in order that the matter could be taken up with the contractor.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Indian Day School, Mud Lake Reserve, Ontario.

With reference to the toilet system installed at the above, the operation of which has been unsatisfactory, I may say that a new type, known as a Water Septic System, equal to that manufactured by the Canadian Sanitation Company, was specified in accordance with the recommendation in the building data form submitted by the Indian Affairs Branch for this project.

When the plans of this building were being prepared the use of this system was discussed between officers of the Indian Affairs Branch and this Service and an inspection was made of a similar system being installed in a new Separate School at Vankleek Hill, Ontario. In this discussion it was pointed out by our officer that there was no evidence that a system of this type would operate satisfactorily. However, in view of the use of this system in other schools and the desire to obtain an inexpensive indoor system for use in larger Indian Day Schools where a piped water supply is not available, it was decided by the Indian Affairs officers to try the system at the Mud Lake School as a test case.

Enquiries are being made by this Service to determine whether the failure of the Mud Lake system is due to the design of the equipment or to the manner in which it was installed; and also regarding the operation of the system at Vankleek Hill.

A further report on this matter will be submitted as soon as we have received replies to our enquiries.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Sir,

When the new school was built at Mud Lake there was no school bell provided and it is suggested by the Council of the Band that the bell in the Council Hall be taken down and placed at the new school. I believe it could be placed on supports on the ground near the door, with the bell rope high enough so persons unauthorized could not ring the bell. In order to do this the rope could be passed through the top of the bell through a hole in the wall to the class room. The cost would be possibly $10.00 or $15.00.

In most homes there are no clocks and they depend upon the bell for their time and also for sending their children to school. There is also the matter of warning in case of fire. Ringing the bell for various causes has been a long established custom on this Reserve and the members miss the bell considerably.

Would it not be possible to have the bell taken from the present Council Hall which is closed up generally during the week and erected on the school as proposed. The Council is willing to give the bell for this purpose and it is also necessary to take the bell down from its present location as the timbers are no longer safe.

Your letter 25-1-5 of June 3rd requested me to advise when the manufacturer's representative had visited the Mud Lake school in regard to the chemical closets. The arrangements were not carried out as stated in my letter but Mr. Wilford, the contractor, commenced alterations on Monday unknown to me. I do not know whether the manufacturer's representative came through Peterborough or not nor have I seen Mr. Wilford, so I called Mr. Turner, the plumber, who sub-contracted. I was at the Reserve yesterday and saw the work being completed.

Apparently the work entailed digging of a 12 x 12 x 3 ft. disposal bed six feet below the surface in front of the school. Eight foot by thirty inch tanks under each set of toilets were plugged and the level was raised to cover and seal the copper tube from each toilet, 10" in diameter. The present tanks will be maintained at the present level sealing the area of each, which is approximately 24 sq. feet and reducing the area exposed, the 10" diameter copper tubes under each toilet. The overflow will go to the disposal bed. In addition to this, whereas one overhead ventilator was connected to both toilets, there will be a separate one for each. This, if it will work, should rectify the trouble.
The Secretary,

I am somewhat skeptical of the efficiency of the disposal bed to handle the overflow. This disposal bed is seven feet below the grade and it is questionable whether the type of soil which forms the walls of this disposal bed will absorb the overflow. It would appear to me, from what I can recall of the original excavation, of the school, where the rainfall lay in the bottom for some days that this disposal bed would just fill up and remain that way and not take the overflow. If this should happen the pumping out of the tanks would have to be resorted to.

However, I hope and trust this arrangement will work satisfactorily.

GENERAL CONDITIONS

The following General Conditions shall govern and apply to all trades and sub-contract work under this specification.

SITE: The site of the building will be as shown on the accompanying site plan. The precise location of the building on the site will be fixed by the Indian Agent and shall be ascertained by the Contractor when he inspects the site.

SECURITY DEPOSIT: The amount of the security deposit cheque forwarded to the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources by the bidder whose tender has been accepted will be forfeited if such bidder declines to enter into a contract when called upon to do so or fails to commence work within a period of one week after being notified of the acceptance of his tender.

SCHEDULE OF UNIT PRICES: The Contractor shall submit immediately his tender is accepted a detailed schedule of unit prices of all materials worked or in place, which shall, upon approval of the Engineer, be used as a basis for progress payments.

The prices so submitted shall be the basis for adjustments for any alterations, additions and omissions in connection with the work during the period of the contract.

There shall also be submitted at the same time a classification of costs at the schedule of unit prices submitted, aggregating the total contract price.

CHARACTER OF WORK: All the various works are to be executed in a substantial and workmanlike manner and of the best materials of their several kinds and in accordance with the drawings, specification and instructions given from time to time by the Supervising Architect or Engineer and to the entire satisfaction of the Minister or any person delegated by him.
CONTRACTOR'S RESPONSIBILITY: The Contractor shall furnish all materials, utensils, scaffolding, equipment and apparatus and all transportation and labour that may be required for the complete and satisfactory erection of the building.

He shall be entirely and alone responsible for the work and material supplied by all sub-contractors whom he may employ. The specification for each sub-contractor's work of the various trades shall be co-operative with the general and labour conditions.

COMPETENT FOR MAN: The Contractor shall give efficient supervision to the work and shall keep at all time a competent foreman on the works, who shall represent him in his absence.

TEMPORARY BUILDINGS: The Contractor shall erect at his own expense any temporary buildings or workshop that may be required for the workmen or for the proper storage and protection of materials against damage. He shall also provide an earth closet or other temporary privy as may be required for the use of the workmen.

INSURANCE: The Contractor shall maintain and pay for fire insurance on the building in a reputable Fire Insurance Company for an amount equal to not less than Eighty per cent (80%) of the value of the work done and material delivered on the site; any loss sustained by fire to be payable to the Department and the Contractor as their joint interests may be determined.

The Contractor shall maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims under the Workmen's Compensation Acts and from any other claims for damages for personal injury including death, which may arise from his operations under this contract.

PLANT: The Contractor is to furnish all transportation, labour, scaffolding, tools, derricks, ladders, moulds, patterns and all forms and materials or equipment whatsoever in connection with the same to the full extent found necessary or requisite in the opinion of the Engineer for the due and proper execution and completion of all works embraced in this contract. It shall be in the power of the Engineer to order off the premises any equipment, etc., which may be found defective, unfit or otherwise unsuitable for the proper execution of the works and the Contractor shall replace the same by a suitable and approved class of equipment, etc. Upon completion of the works, the plant shall be promptly removed from the site of the work.

CANADIAN MANUFACTURE: All material used in the erection of the building shall, as far as possible, be produced or manufactured in Canada.

DEFECTIVE MATERIALS: No defective material, worked or otherwise, shall be brought to the site or used in the work and should the Contractor in case such material be brought, refuse to remove such material and replace the same with proper material, the Minister or the Engineer may cause the same to be removed and replaced with proper material at the cost and charge of the Contractor and deduct the expenses from the amount due or accruing due.
SETTING OUT OF WORK: The setting out of work shall rest solely with the Contractor who will be responsible for the same and if any discrepancies should be found he will have to alter and make good the same at his own expense.

CARE AND PROTECTION OF WORKS: The Contractor will be held absolutely responsible for the care of the works from the commencement of same to its completion. He shall provide, erect and maintain all necessary guards, rails, fences, night lights, etc. All possible care will be taken to protect the works against accident or injury from fire, design, elements, or other causes, as the entire work is at the Contractor's risk who will be held responsible for all accidents or injury that may happen to the work or to individuals or property until the building is formally taken over by the Department. The Contractor shall take particular care of all finished work which shall be thoroughly protected from injury. Should any damage arise from any cause the same shall be made good by the Contractor to the satisfaction of the Minister.

OVERLOADING: The Contractor will be required to make good for any damage caused by overloading any construction. No load is to be placed on concrete work nor shall it be subject to blows or other strains until it has obtained its permanent set.

The Department will not be held accountable for anything injured from any cause whatsoever, incorrect, stolen or lost.

FREEZING WEATHER: During freezing weather all ingredients for concrete, cement, mortar and plaster shall be heated before using to a temperature of at least 40 degrees Fahrenheit. Concrete and cement finish shall be protected by adequate covering until the initial set is attained. Registers shall be installed and connected with the heating system as soon as practicable and until this is in operation such other methods as are necessary shall be adopted for complete protection of the works.

The Contractor will be required to make good any damage by frost to materials on the site or to work in place.

DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATION: The works comprised under the contract are shown on the accompanying blueprint drawings and specification. The drawings and specification are intended to be co-operative and to provide for and comprise everything necessary for the completion of the work. Any work or material shown on the drawings even if not particularly described in the specification or vice versa, is to be done or supplied by the Contractor as if it were both shown and specified.

If any portion of the work is not specified or indicated on the drawings, but is implied or may reasonably be considered as necessary to complete the work, such work is to be carried out by the Contractor without extra charge in accordance with the best local practice.

Should any dispute arise respecting the true intent and meaning of the drawings or specifications the same is to be decided by the engineer, whose decision will be final.
All lettering on the drawings is to be considered as part of the specification and contract.

Drawings and specifications to be produced when required, carefully used and returned to the Department at the completion of the contract.

In all cases figured dimensions are to be followed in preference to those ascertained by scale.

NO DEVIATIONS: No deviations are to be made from the drawings and specification without written authority from the Department and should any part of the work be altered or executed in an unsatisfactory manner it will have to be taken down and reconstructed at the expense of the Contractor, and any damage that may occur from any cause shall be made good without extra expense to the satisfaction of the Minister.

WATER SUPPLY: The Contractor, when examining the site of the building, shall determine the location and character of the most convenient approved water supply available for building operations.

REMOVE DEBRIS, ETC.: The Contractor shall remove from the site as directed all surplus soil, building rubbish or debris resulting from the execution of the work and at the completion of the contract shall leave the building and site in perfect condition.

STATUTORY DECLARATION: Upon completion of the works, the Contractor shall be required to submit to the Department a statement attested by statutory declaration showing that all works performed and materials supplied are free of all lawful liens or claims.

EXCAVATION

SITE CLEARANCE: The Contractor shall clear the site of the building of all obstructions, including trees and their roots as necessary for the proper carrying out of the work.

Existing trees and shrubs in the vicinity of the works shall be protected as directed by the Engineer against damage during the progress of operations.

STAKES AND BATTER BOARDS: The building shall be accurately laid out and such stakes, batter boards, etc., as required properly set.

SOD AND SOIL: Carefully remove all sod and top soil as directed by the Engineer over the area of the building and for five feet beyond on all sides and pile near the works where directed. Such soil may be used for grading as directed after completion of the building.

GENERAL EXCAVATION: Excavate all earth, stone, rock and other materials for basement, footings, foundation walls and such other work as required to the proper depths, forms and sizes. Footings shall rest on suitable undisturbed level bottom. The excavations shall be sufficiently wider than the foundation walls for proper form construction and waterproofing. Excavations shall be kept free of water.

BACK FILL: After construction of walls, etc., all remaining excavated areas shall be back filled with suitable approved material, well puddled and rammed at each foot in height to within one foot of top of grade.

GRADING: The earth, etc., removed from the excavation shall be graded and levelled to approval and then covered with top soil to level directed by Engineer. All excess earth and debris shall be removed from the site and disposed of where and as directed.
DRAINAGE

WEPPING TILE: Lay a drain of 4" agricultural weeping tile completely around basement foundation walls at bottom of footings as shown on drawings with branch lines 6'0" long running through footings and under basement floor slab where indicated. Where each of these branches passes through footings, they shall be of 4" cast iron pipe of same length as width of footing.

Weeping tile shall be laid with 1/8" open joints protected with tar paper strips 4" wide and then covered with not less than 12" of broken stone and gravel.

CATCH BASIN: Construct catch basin of concrete in position shown, or where directed by the Engineer, and connect with weeping tile drain.

VITRIFIED TILE: Lay a drain of best quality 4" vitrified salt glazed, earthenware pipe, from catch basin to sump. If the extent of this drain is not indicated, the Contractor shall include in his tender price an amount for installing same to any point selected by the Engineer within 100'0" of the building.

Lay a similar tile drain, or drains if shown, from catch basin to the proper positions at basement footings and connect same to cast iron basement floor drains.

During laying, each section of vitrified tile shall be solidly supported above bottom of trench and socket-jointed with cement. After jointing, solid beds of soil shall be well packed under pipes.

IRON DRAINS: Run a 4" cast iron pipe drain, or drains if shown, under basement floor from floor drains to outside of foundation walls under footings and connect to the vitrified tile drains specified above, running to catch basin.

Provide and install all required Ys, bends, etc., and a C.I. trap and floor strainer to each basement floor outlet.

SUMP: Construct where directed a sump of 2" planks framed to 4" x 4" posts.

BACK FILLING: Back filling over all tile and iron drains shall be carefully executed with approved material in a manner to avoid disturbing pipes.
CONCRETE AND MASONRY

GENERAL: Construct all concrete, masonry work and other such work as may be required for the proper erection of the building of the full size and as indicated on the drawings.

FORMWORK: All forms in contact with concrete shall be of dressed lumber, sound and free from knot holes, cracks, etc., thoroughly braced and wired to prevent bulging and sagging, so that concrete work will be true to form and line. The forms must be clean and free from shavings and foreign matter before concrete is placed.

PIPES AND DUCTS: Formwork for any openings for pipes, ducts, conduits, etc., required shall be set before concrete is poured.

NAILING BLOCKS: Any nailing blocks shown on drawings shall be of the size shown and spaced as indicated.

GRAVEL: Only approved gravel shall be used. It shall be composed of sharp, clean sand free from loam, dirt and organic matter and stones not larger than will pass through a 2 1/4" ring. If suitable gravel is not obtainable, crushed stone of similar size and sand that will pass through a 1/4" sieve shall be used.

Stones used in reinforced concrete shall not be larger than will pass through a 3/4" ring.

CEMENT: All cement used shall be Canadian "Portland" of best quality to conform to the Standard Specification for cement adopted by the Canadian Engineering Standards Association. Only fresh cement shall be used and it must be stored when on the site in a weathertight place. No cement that, in the opinion of the Engineer, is defective will be accepted. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, make all tests of cement and concrete that may be directed by the Engineer.

MIXING: All concrete shall be thoroughly mixed, preferably in a mechanical mixer, in the proportions specified. Only clean water from approved sources shall be used. Each batch shall be mixed at least one minute in a mechanical mixer or to the approval of Engineer if mixed by hand.

PROPORTION: All concrete shall be mixed in the proportion of one part cement to six parts gravel. The water, including aggregate moisture, shall not exceed 5 1/4 gallons per sack of cement. If crushed stone is used, proportion shall be one part cement to two parts sand and four parts crushed stone. A reasonable proportion of stone fillers may be used if approved by the Engineer. Such stones shall be clean and sharp and shall not penetrate more than half the thickness of the walls nor be set within two inches of faces.

PLACING: All concrete shall be deposited within fifteen minutes of mixing. It shall be spaded and rodded so as to minimize air spaces and produce smooth surfaces when the forms are removed.
After forms have been removed, any voids found shall be filled and the top of walls, etc., brought to a true level with mortar of one part cement to three parts clean sharp sand.

Exposed surfaces of concrete shall be protected from too fast drying for a period of at least seven days after being deposited.

FOOTINGS: Footings shall be of size shown, laid on solid bottom at depth indicated on drawings.

Tops of footings under wood posts in basement shall project 3" above finished floor and shall have a layer of 3-ply asphalt roofing between concrete and bottom of post.

DOWELS: Set a 5/8" diameter metal dowel, 6" long, to project 2" above concrete at centre of each basement post footing to receive wood post over.

FOUNDATION WALLS: Carry up foundation walls to level shown on drawings.

FLOOR SLABS: Level under required areas, remove all loose material and lay a bed of broken stone and gravel 5" thick, wetted and well tamped in place. On this foundation lay 4" thick concrete floor slabs set to fall as required to floor drains where indicated. All slabs shall be reinforced with "Pedlar People" or equal expanded metal reinforcement, weight .495 per sq. ft. When slabs are hard but not thoroughly dry, finish with a 1:3 cement and sand mix 1" thick trowelled to a smooth surface. In the angle formed by floor slab and foundation walls, carry up cement floor finish on walls to form a coved base as shown on wall section detail.

WATERPROOFING: Mop over the exterior and interior top of basement footings, the entire exterior surface of foundation walls to within 3" of finished grade and the interior of foundation walls from footings to top of cement base with two coats of hot coal tar pitch. In the angle formed by foundation walls and footings on exterior side, mop on a strip of tarred building felt 12" wide.

ENTRANCE STEP: Set in a precast concrete step to entrance with wash to top.
BRICK WORK: All common brick and face brick to be sound and well-burned. They shall be thoroughly wetted before being laid. All bed and vertical mortar joints shall be well filled and shall not exceed 3/8" in thickness.

CHIMNEY: Carry up chimney from foundation to roof in approved common brick laid in 1:1:6 cement, lime and sand mortar, forming cleanouts and connections as required. Walls to be of thickness shown and to form clear open flue.

Chimney above roof line shall be of approved face brick laid in 1:3 cement and sand mortar with 10% of lime added to the cement. Lay cap bricks in pattern shown and weather the top with cement mortar.

CLEANOUTS: Set in place cast-iron cleanout door and frame, size approximately 8" x 10".

THIMBLES: Set thimble in proper position for smoke pipe.

FUEL CHUTE: Provide and set in position shown a heavy steel fuel chute, size 17" x 24" with steel panel door, gravity latch and chain for remote control.
CARPENTRY AND JOINERY

FORM WORK: The Contractor shall erect all forms for concrete work as specified under Concrete and Masonry.

MATERIALS: All lumber shall be well seasoned, dry and of the respective kinds and grades specified hereunder.

Dimension lumber to be six square sized, of No.1 Common Pinus Strobus (hereinafter referred to as white pine) or Merchantable spruce.

Shiplap sheathing and boards to be of No.1 common white pine.

Siding to be of white pine "D Selects" or cedar, "Clear A".

Shingles to be Eastern white cedar "Clear Extras" or B.C. cedar XXXXX.

All the following described lumber to be kiln dried:

Exterior and interior trim to be of white pine "C Selects and Better".

Door and window frames, sash and exterior doors to be of white pine "No.1 outs".

Interior doors to be of Douglas fir "No.2 clear and better".

Finished flooring to be of 1"x4" Douglas fir, "No.2 Clear and Better, Edge Grain" T.&G. or 1"x2" No.2 birch.

Staircase or staircases shown on drawings, to be of Douglas fir, "No.2 Clear and Better" except treads and handrail which shall be of No.1 birch.

V-joint lining to be of Douglas fir, "No.2 Clear and Better", or white pine "D Selects".

All lumber to be graded as follows:

Pine in accordance with official grading rules of the White Pine Bureau.

Spruce in accordance with standard grading rules for Eastern Canadian Spruce lumber adopted by Canadian Lumbermen's Association.

Douglas fir in accordance with standard grading rules adopted by British Columbia Lumber and Shingle Manufacturers Ltd.
Sizes specified or shown on drawings for shiplap, boarding, flooring, etc., are nominal.

Mouldings, trim, etc., to be nearest to size shown or specified that conforms with local standard stock patterns unless otherwise specified.

DRESSED LUMBER: All woodwork throughout the building where exposed to view or to the weather is to be dressed for painters' finish.

FRAME CONSTRUCTION: All framing throughout to be constructed in the strongest manner in accordance with the working drawings and following the best practice. All members to be set plumb, true and level, braced and bridged as necessary and strongly nailed, spiked, bolted or otherwise fastened together. Openings for ducts, etc., shall be framed in a manner to avoid the weakening of structural or bearing timbers.

BASEMENT POSTS: Set where shown in basement, wood posts of size and in positions indicated, S.A.S. with 1" chamfered corners. Posts to be secured at bottom with metal dowels as described under Concrete and Masonry.

BEAMS: Build up beams of 2" planks to sizes indicated and set where shown with all joints over bearings.

SILLS: Exterior frame walls shall have sills of size indicated laid in long lengths, the pieces halved together at corners and bedded level in mortar in position shown.

FLOOR JOISTS: Floor joists shall be of size shown, spaced and set as indicated on drawings, to form a true level bearing for floors. All trimmers, headers and joists supporting parallel partitions shall be doubled.

CROSS BRIDGING: Floor joists to be braced with 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" x 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" cross bridging, placed as shown accurately cut and fitted between joists.

WALL FRAMING: All frame walls and partitions shall be framed with studs of sizes and spacing indicated and capped with a plate of two pieces of same size as studs laid in long lengths, with joints made over studs. Studding to be doubled at angles around openings and elsewhere as required.

CEILING JOISTS: Ceiling joists to be of sizes indicated, spaced as shown and set to form a level backing for ceiling.

Joists over classroom to be in two lengths strongly spliced together to bridge span.

OPENING TO ATTIC: Form a hatch opening to attic where directed, with rebated frame and set in a T. & G. batten cover, hinged to open inwards and line with hard wallboard on lower side.
GRILLED VENTS: When shown on drawing frame for vents in classroom ceiling, and fit in an approved metal grill to each.

ROOF FRAMING: Frame all roofs at pitch shown with rafters, ties and braces, etc., of sizes and spacing indicated. Rafters to be notched and spiked to wall plate and accurately butted to ridge board set at a true level. All hip rafters to be 2" deeper than common rafters.

SHIPLAP SHEATHING: Line the following and any additional surfaces indicated on drawings with 1" x 8" shiplap closely jointed and strongly nailed to each bearing:

- Both sides of exterior wall studs, the underside of first floor ceiling joists, the surface of all roofs.

PARTITION SHEATHING: Line both sides of all partitions with 1" x 8" boards S.I.S., closely butted and strongly nailed to each bearing stud.

SUBFLOORS: Cover floor joists of all rooms with 1" x 8" floor boards, S.I.S. laid diagonally, and rigidly nailed to each joist.

BUILDING PAPERS: All building felts and papers, to be carefully laid with at least 2" lap at all joints and well tucked behind window and door frames. Cover the whole of the exterior shiplap sheathing including that to roofs with tarred building felt of first quality, weight 15½ per square and the surface of all interior wall shiplap and subfloors with waterproof building paper weight about 4½ per square.

SIDING: Line the exterior wall surfaces where shown on drawings with 1" x 8" bevelled siding, all accurately cut and close jointed. Set water table as shown.

CORNER BOARDS: Set in place at angles of building where shown 1 1/8" thick corner boards of widths to provide 4½" face on each side of angle.

SHINGLES: Cover the pitched roofs with shingles laid 4½" to weather; each shingle twice as laid with galvanized iron shingle nails. Line the small gable to rear elevation in a similar manner but with shingles laid 6" to weather. Lay shingles accurately out to form weatherproof Boston hips and ridges.

First floor classrooms from baseboard to picture mould.

Cost rooms from baseboards to top of door casings.

The entire walls of vestibule.

INTERIOR TRIM: All interior trim to be sanded smooth, free from mill marks, nail heads counter sunk and ready for painters' finish.

BLACKBOARDS: Provide and install on classroom walls where shown and of size indicated on drawings, manufactured asbestos slateboard, "Black Asbestolite" or equal; held in place with quarter round mould and capped at top with picture mould and casing and provided with chalkrail with mould under and apron all as shown on detail drawing. The inside surface of door to furnace room to be lined with G.I. as specified under carpentry.

VENTILATORS: Supply and install on roof two first-class approved G.I. ventilators of general type and size shown.

COPING: Construct and set the ornamental G.I. coping over entrance as shown.

GUARANTEE: The Contractor shall furnish the Department with a written guarantee that he will make good, at his own expense, any leaks or other defects in the roofs and any damage caused by such leaks or defects in the roof or flashing that develop within a period of twelve months from date of completion of the building.

KICK PLATE

KICK PLATE: The Contractor shall provide and set a 14 gauge, bevelled edge, brass kick plate 8" high to each entrance door, fixed with round headed brass screws. The cost of kick plates to be included in tender price.
HARDWARE

ROUGH HARDWARE: The Contractor shall supply and install all rough and structural hardware such as nails, spikes, bolts, sash hangers, etc., which may be required for the complete erection of the building in accordance with the full intent of the drawings and specification as well as any hardware specified under "Concrete and Masonry".

ALLOWANCE FOR FINISHING HARDWARE $175.00.

The Contractor shall include the above named sum in the amount of his tender to cover the cost of all finishing hardware. Such sum shall include the actual trade cost of material plus freight charges. He shall, upon completion of the work, submit to the Department all invoices for such materials and bills of freight charges. Any part of the sum not expended will be deducted from the contract price.

All finishing hardware including locks and their trim, knobs, butts, latches, casement and balanced sash and storm sash fasteners, and other fittings required shall be selected to the approval of the Engineer.

INSTALLATION: All hardware shall be attached in a neat and accurate manner with screws to match finish.

SEPTIC CLOSETS

Provide and install two septic closets in each of the two toilets. Each battery of two closets to be connected with a tank of 500 gals. capacity.

The system to be as manufactured by Canadian Sanitation Co., Toronto and Hamilton, or equal and installed in accordance with manufacturer's directions and to be complete with all accessories including vent pipes.

Vents shall be carried up wall of building and through roof with weatherproof connections.

Closets shall be of vitreous white china with oak seats and covers.
PAINTING AND GLAZING

GENERAL: The following specifications, unless otherwise stipulated, are intended to cover the finishing of all interior and exterior surfaces, where exposed to view or weather throughout the entire building.

WORKMANSHIP: All painting shall be carried out as rapidly as the completion of the various sections of work permit, by skilled workmen, strictly in accordance with accepted standards for first class work.

MATERIALS: All materials used on the work shall be of high grade quality of standard brands of approved manufacturers, delivered on the job in the manufacturer's original sealed containers and applied in accordance with the manufacturer's directions, except where hereinafter specified otherwise.

COMPLETION: Upon completion of the building the contractor shall clean off all spots from floors, walls, trim, glass, etc., refinish all damaged work; replace cracked or broken glass, and shall leave the building in a clean and orderly condition, subject to approval of the Engineer.

PAINTING CONDITIONS: Before commencing work, the contractor shall carefully inspect all surfaces to ensure that the surfaces to be painted are thoroughly dry, clean, and in suitable condition to receive finish, and no work shall be done under unfavourable conditions.
PAINT AND COLOUR: All work covered by this specification is proposed to be carried out with the following paints, unless otherwise specifically stipulated. All colours stated are subject to change by the Engineer and shall be confirmed in writing before such work is undertaken.

Exterior walls, doors, sash, trim, etc. -
gloss white outside house paint.

Roof Shingles -
red creosote shingle stain.

dark slate gray porch floor paint.

Hard Surface Wallboard -
ivory washable interior wall paint.

Insulation wallboard -
semi gloss white washable interior wall paint.

Burlap mould -
washable interior wall paint to match wall board to which it is applied.

Interior Trim -
ivory washable interior wall paint

Interior Doors, stair risers, balusters, handrails, etc. -
light oak stain and varnish.

Wood Flooring, stair treads and closed stringers. -
oil finish "Hippo" or equal.

Basement ceiling - see insulation wallboard.

EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR PAINTWORK: THREE COAT WORK.

All paintwork is to be carried out in accordance with the best practice for three coat work. Before priming coat is applied all knots and sap wood shall be given a coat of pure orange shellac.

After priming coat has been applied and permitted to dry, all nail holes, cracks, and other defects shall be filled with linseed oil and whiting putty, and the work sanded smooth and wiped clean.

All thinning for priming and second coats to be done with pure linseed oil and turpentine mixed in accordance with manufacturer's directions.

If thinner brushing consistency is desired small amounts of pure turpentine may be added.

INSULATING (SOFT) WALLBOARD:

All soft wall board shall be sized with approved brand of sizing liquid added in proper proportion to priming coat, and finished as for three coat paint work.

INTERIOR STAIN AND VARNISH:

All interior doors, stair handrails, balusters, risers, inside face closed stringers, etc., shall be finished with one coat oil stain of approved colour and finished with two coats of high quality hard varnish applied in accordance to the best practice for such work.

WOOD FLOOR FINISH: All inside wood flooring, stair treads and carpet strips shall be sanded smooth and thoroughly cleaned after which shall be applied three coats of floor oil in accordance with manufacturer's directions.

BASEMENT WALLS: All masonry or concrete walls in basement rooms, except fuel room, shall be given two coats of approved brand aluminum paint, applied in accordance with the manufacturer's directions.

BASEMENT FLOOR: All cement flooring in basement shall be given a priming coat and two finishing coats of approved brand cement floor paint applied in accordance with the manufacturer's directions.

SHINGLES: All wood roof or wall shingles shall be given two coats of approved brand 'Osmoata' shingle stain, applied in accordance with the manufacturer's directions.

GALVANIZED IRON: All metal flashing or roofing where exposed to view, shall be prepared for painting by the proper application of copper acetate, copper chloride, or copper sulphate solution, and finished with two coats of oil paint to match adjacent surface.

GLAZING: All glass throughout the building shall be double diamond, properly installed by bedding in putty and finishing with springs and putty or wood stops.
HOT AIR HEATING

GENERAL: The Contractor shall provide all labour, and material and install a hot air heating system as hereafter described with hot air registers and cool air returns placed in all rooms, etc., in which such registers are indicated on the plans.

The positions of registers may be varied if so recommended by the contractor for the better circulation of heat throughout the building.

The system shall be complete in all respects and ready for continuous operation. All fittings and accessory materials not herein specified but necessary to complete the installation shall be furnished by the Contractor.

The Contractor shall furnish the Department with a plan and schedule showing the layout and stating the size of all hot and cool air registers, leaders and ducts, the furnace (full description) and other apparatus proposed to be installed. No work shall be commenced until such plan and schedule have been approved by the Department.

FURNACE: Furnish and set up complete in basement one first grade cast iron hot air coal burning furnace of approved make with casing complete and firing tools. The furnace shall be located approximately where indicated on plan and shall be of ample capacity to heat and maintain the building in accordance with the guarantee as stated hereafter.

SMOKE PIPE: Furnish and run a smoke pipe from the furnace to the flue. Pipe to be of No. 24 gauge galvanized iron full size of collar of furnace. Pipe to be well supported and properly connected to the chimney with air tight cast iron ring.

COOL AIR SUPPLY: Run galvanized iron ducts for the cool air returns from the registers to the furnace. The cross sectional area of these ducts shall not be less than the combined areas of all leader pipes.

HOT AIR LEADERS: Furnish and set up hot air leaders of ample size and made of bright I.X. tin or No.26 gauge galvanized sheet iron with side seams locked, and joints double seamed or lapped not less than 1½ inches. All pipes shall be properly connected with the furnace registers and wall stacks and secured to ceiling or joists. All leaders to be provided with dampers located within two feet of Furnace casing. All leaders running within 12" of woodwork shall be covered with two layers of asbestos paper.

Where a leader is run within one inch of any woodwork the woodwork is to be covered with asbestos paper and tin or sheet iron over the paper.

WALL STACKS: All wall stacks shall be of materials as specified for leaders and covered with not less than one thickness of asbestos felt, weight, 12 lbs. per 100 sq. ft.

BENDS: All bends in leaders and smoke pipe to be made with three-piece elbows.

GUARANTEE: The Contractor shall furnish a written guarantee that the furnace and heating equipment as installed by him shall be of sufficient capacity to heat all rooms with registers connected with the furnace to 70° Fahrenheit when the outside temperature is at the minimum normally experienced in the locality.

My dear Mr. Scott,

I have recently received a letter from the teacher who was appointed to Chemong, which leads me to enquire if something cannot be done to put the house at Chemong Lake in fit condition for a family to live in. The information contained in Mr. Cork's letter is substantially as follows:

That the house was built over forty years ago by the New England Company, and connected with it was over one hundred acres of land, but when the Company withdrew, eight or nine years ago, the Indians bought the whole property for $2500 (Twenty-Five Hundred Dollars) and it now belongs to the Band.

The teacher who served under the New England Company occupied the house for several years. After he left it was occupied by an Indian and his family, and this continued for some seven years. A part of the time this Indian paid $2 (Two Dollars) per month rent.

The Indians now want Mr. Cork to take the house at a rental of $50 (Fifty Dollars) per annum. The house at one time was a good one, but is too large for an ordinary family, and is in a bad state of disrepair. There are a lot of sheds and stables but they also are in a terribly dilapidated condition. It is thought that no paint has been put upon the house since the time it was built, and some of the floors are in very
very bad condition. The wall paper is hanging in tatters in most of the rooms, and in some places the plastering is off. The whole place is in an exceedingly dirty condition. Mr. Cork thinks it would take from $250 to $300 (Two Hundred and Fifty to Three Hundred Dollars) to put part of the house in a state fit for decent people to live in. The surroundings outside the house are all right and quite attractive. Mr. Cork has not said anything to the Council, deeming it better, I suppose, that anything of that kind would have more weight if coming from the Department.

You will readily see what all this leads to. We are very desirous of effecting an improvement in the Day School, and this, I think, Mr. Cork is capable of accomplishing; but if he is to remain it is essential that he have a reasonably comfortable place to live in and this necessitates somewhat extensive repairs. As we have no claim upon the property in any shape or form it is of course out of the question for us to undertake the necessary work. I sincerely hope and trust that the Department may be able to make such representations to the Indian Council as will result in having the dwelling and the necessary out-buildings put in thorough repair.

Yours faithfully,

Duncan G. Scott, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Mr. Cork, although a married man, is living alone in a small rented house near the school. He told me his family, who live in Toronto, were not disposed to spend the winter on the Island. It would take about $300.00 to make it habitable and remove some of the tumble-down outbuildings which surround it, but, if put in order, it would make a very comfortable residence for the teacher and his family.
