Brick house, about 12 or 15 rooms, good horse stable, good well water, cistern, orchard, lawn, and about one acre of garden ground, in all, about two acres. Beautiful trees and shrubs also surround the lawn. There is also a good wood shed. The building is beautifully situated near Mud Lake shore, about 50 yards distance, and a half mile from Buckhorn Lake shore. Rose Lake, Long Lake, and other smaller fish abound in these lakes. This dwelling is situated in Cheltenham Village, about 11 miles from the city of Peterborough, and a few miles from surrounding villages; post office a quarter of a mile; handy getting to Peterborough by stage or steam boat every day.

Sir: Reference letter #25-1-8, Oct. 6th, 1928.

I looked carefully over the mission house recently at Mud Lake Reserve and find that the original amount of Three Hundred Dollars to Four Hundred Dollars suggested for repairs to same to be considerably out in my estimation.

The house is a twelve room brick structure and it is to be regretted that it has gotten into such a condition as it now stands. The biggest item that I can see in the repairing would be the whole roof re-shingled for which I am getting a quote. The walls are considerably blackened and the whole place needs re-decorating inside. The brick on the north exposure needs re-pointing. The foundation looks very good indeed with the exception of one window having fallen off taking part of the foundation with it. Otherwise the house is in excellent condition and it would be a pity to let it go. I rather think it would be considerably larger than the teacher's requirements. He went through it with me and he suggested walling up part of it so that he could use about half, but I rather think this would be costly unless temporary partitions were put in.

I have approached several contractors to give me a figure on this work but as it is twenty-two miles from Peterborough and a long way to draw material I have been unable to get a definite quote.
Along with the other things I have mentioned flooring would have to be laid as the soft wood used has been scored badly. Different families of Indians have lived in it from time to time and have not kept the property in good condition.

I hope to have more definite information on the cost of this work, in the course of a few days, which I will supply you with.

Sir: Reference your letter 25-1-8 of Nov. 21/28, and previous correspondence.

About six weeks ago I looked over the property on the Mud Lake Reserve, known as the mission house. I find it is a very large house having about fourteen rooms not including sheds and it is in a very poor state of repair. Different Indian families have lived in it from time to time and left it in a very dirty condition that, combined with the age of the house and the use it has been put to has made it a very costly item in my estimation to do anything with. The house was built in about 1865 and apparently has had nothing done to it since. This is the actual condition I found the house in. It needs shingling throughout and plastering throughout. The whole brick work needs re-pointing. The whole building needs re-flooring. It needs re-decorating as the walls are all smoked and the chimney is in a very bad state of repair. The north side of the foundation has fallen in to the extent of about 10 feet, the arch of a cellar window having collapsed. The windows throughout need re-glazing and the house needs re-painting throughout.

Now in the matter of seeing what I could do to put this house in livable condition or part of it, I went to one contractor and he estimated One Thousand Dollars. Because of the inaccessibility of the place and the necessity of hauling materials such a long distance it is difficult to get a
contractor to take over the work. However, I located a man in Lakefield who would take over the work and I am enclosing a letter and agreement stating what he would do and what he would expect in payment thereof and you will notice in his agreement that he has not covered all the necessary work.

In connection with your letter to Mr. Lewis, I would be very glad to co-operate with him in getting the work done. I certainly would be very doubtful of the amount of money he can have it done for. I realize that it is better to get some revenue out of this, but there again I do not think the Department is getting sufficient rental if they invest anything near this amount although I think it would be an excellent thing to have the school teacher living on the Reserve. Mr. Lewis and his wife have been boarding at D. E. Whetungs as Mr. Lewis has been doing since he came to the Reserve and although I appreciate him wanting to be in a house of his own, he certainly has not been inconvenienced as stated in your letter.

I would suggest a representative from the Department, if in this vicinity on any other mission, should call and look over this property before anything is done.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Mud and Rice Lake Reserves.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to your re-engagement as senior teacher of the Mud Lake Indian Day School for the next school year, and requesting to be informed as to the salary that will be allowed and the rental charged for the mission house which was recently repaired to be used by you as a residence.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will be pleased to approve of your re-engagement as senior teacher of the Mud Lake School for the next school year. The salary allowed you will be at the rate of $95 per teaching month, the same as was previously paid. Besides, the Department will allow you the use of the house as a residence without any charge against your salary for rental, and it is considered that this should be taken into account in lieu of any increase in your salary as teacher for the next school year. We are arranging to reimburse the band who own the residence to the amount of $100 per annum. In view of the fact that you will be given free use of this residence, it is considered that no charge should be made by you for overseeing the work in the repairs that were recently made to same.

Regarding the water supply, the Department is not prepared at the present time to authorize the drilling of a well, and it is thought that you can continue the same arrangement to obtain a supply of water as you are at present doing.

Mr. Agent Eastwood is being informed accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Morgan Lewis, Esq.,

Curve Lake, Ont.

Sir: Reference your letter 25-1-8, March 23/31.

In reply to your letter of the above date enclosing a copy of letter from Rev. A. D. Irwin, missionary at Curve Lake, I beg to report that I visited the reserve yesterday and met Miss Garveth and Mr. Irwin at Chief Whetung's.

The mission house is occupied by both parties as laid out in the accompanying sketch. You will notice that Miss Garveth has the south-east bedroom on the ground floor and this communicates, by means of sliding doors, with the sleeping room occupied by the Irwins. These doors are not absolutely sound-proof, in fact, the main contention is that any sound or noise which is made in Miss Garveth's room is distinctly audible through these doors.

I recommended to Miss Garveth that she take the three upstairs bedrooms as shown in sketch number two and hand over to Mr. Irwin the room she now occupies on the ground floor. She declined to do this and summing up the whole dispute, this is the main contention. There has been a misunderstanding as to who is responsible for the whole house. Mrs. Irwin claims that she has papers to show that she has claim to the whole house and Miss Garveth says the same thing. However, I think I succeeded in explaining the matter to them. Miss Garveth has Miss Long, the Junior teacher, living with her and possibly needs extra room for this reason.
I would recommend that Mr. Irwin be given the rooms number one, two and three on the ground floor which are the only rooms improved and that Miss Garveth have the choice of any rooms, three of which are improved, on the second floor. This would satisfactorily separate the two parties as the hallway does not interfere in any way with this arrangement. I also divided equally the garden space which was in dispute.

This disposition of the rooms will not be satisfactory to Miss Garveth, but I see no reason why this should not be done, as it is the only way in which Mrs. Irwin will be satisfied. In all there are seven bedrooms upstairs and plenty of room to choose from for both parties and I think one should be upstairs and one down and Miss Garveth, being by herself, can willingly afford to give in to this extent.

In the matter of the substance of Mr. Irwin's letter there has been absolutely no foundation of a statement such as a band member was supposed to have made in connection with rental. I think Mr. Irwin would be well advised to request this information from myself.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, reporting on the disagreement between the Reverend Irwin and Miss Garveth with reference to the occupancy of the Mission House on the Mud Lake Reserve. This house was provided by the Band for the use of the resident missionary and it is the logical thing that he should occupy it and have control of it during the time he is a missionary there. When no missionary was on the Reserve and the teacher, Mr. Lewis, could not get accommodation the house was repaired at the expense of the Band and the teacher was allowed to occupy it, this Department paying the Band a rental of $100.00 per year.

When Miss Garveth was engaged as teacher to the Reserve it was understood that she would have two rooms in the Mission House and this did not give her control of the whole house, it being understood although probably not expressed in writing, that if the missionary occupied the house he would have the control of it as was done in past years when occupied by the minister. The rule must apply at the present time, that is, the house is there for the missionary and Miss Garveth may occupy rooms therein.

The SECRETARY  
Department of Indian Affairs  
Ottawa, Ontario  

Sir:-

Mr. W. Rome, principal of the Mud Lake Day School, writes me that he intends to be married this month and inquires about accommodation at the Mud Lake Reserve. Until recently, the Mission House has been allowed the teachers as residence and was repaired in 1929 for this purpose. Mr. Lewis, a former teacher was granted the privilege of living there when he married. As there is practically no accommodation for a married teacher on the Reserve with exception of this I suggest that Mr. Rome be granted the use of Mission House.

It is now occupied by James McCue as caretaker. He pays the band $3.00 a month. As his term is now expired and he is living on as there has been new demand for same, he could be moved on short notice.

I also suggest at this time that Mr. Rome be advanced to the same salary as Mr. Lewis received. He would be difficult to replace as a teacher and his influence, aside from teaching has been of great value to the whole band.
He has organized seasonable games on the Reserve both amongst the school children and the older members. This has promoted better feeling and is of interest to all. The hockey team played a number of games with the villages near the Reserve and did quite well. There are a number of boys just past school age with nothing to do in the winter months and Mr. Rome has endeavoured to get them interested in something. Under ordinary conditions most of these boys would be out working but jobs are difficult to find at present.

Your obedient servant

Agent
Mud and Rice Lakes Agency
Ottawa, August 11, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, recommending that permission to live in the mission house on the reserve be granted Mr. W. Rome, senior teacher of the Mud Lake Indian Day School, after his coming marriage.

In this connection I have to say that this building is the property of the Band, and, when same was occupied by the former teacher, Mr. Morgan Lewis, it is understood he paid rental at the rate of $100 per annum. If the building is used by Mr. Rome, will the Band require that he pay rental for same, and, if so, what amount? Further, would they be in favour of allowing Mr. Rome to occupy the house? Please state, also, if you have been obtaining the rental from James McCue at the rate of $3.00 per month. Should the Band agree to the occupancy of the house by Mr. Rome, it would be necessary to give Mr. McCue notice.

I may add that the Department will approve of Mr. Rome living in the mission house, provided there is no objection on the part of the Band and an arrangement is made as to any rental that may be charged him.

With reference to your suggestion, that Mr. Rome be granted an increase in salary, equal to that paid the former teacher, Mr. Lewis, I have to say that, under the regulations of the Treasury Board, no increases in salary can be made during the present fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

MEMORANDUM:—

Re Muncey School.

On Wednesday, the 21st ultimo, I visited the Lower Muncey School, which has been taught by Mr. John L. Case, an Indian, for a number of years. There was only one child in attendance and there had only been one for some days with an average of two for a month past. Inquiry revealed the fact that there only five children of school age in the section. I would suggest, therefore, that this school be closed and Mr. Case informed that his services will no longer be required. These children can be enrolled at the Institute.

The school building was erected in 1857 by Chief Waubuno with funds collected in England. The Department put on a new roof a few years ago and quite extensive repairs would be necessary if the school was to be kept in operation. If the suggestion to close the school is approved I presume that no action will be taken.

April 2nd, 1918.

To His Highness King George the Fifth,
and Cabinet Ministers:

We appeal to your humble consideration:
The Munsey Indians of Caradoc Reserve School has been established since A.D. 1844. It went on the same as any other school on the Reserve until about six years ago. The School was closed owing to the fact that there were not enough children to attend. The last two or three years we have had enough children to attend. We petitioned the Indian Department at Ottawa, and the Hon. Department politely refused to accede to our request.

According to the Treaties, Frederick Haldimand A.D.1795, treaty was made with various tribes of Indians. We are one of the tribes. We used to get blankets, guns, kettles and many other things until about A.D. 1848. Ministers came on the Reserve telling us to turn this into a school fund and finally the Indians consented. Ever since then we were entitled to the school. As the Hon. Indian Department refused to grant our request, we claim we are treated unjustly.

We do not see why we are used as such, though we have shown our loyalty to the Empire in sending our brave warriors to the Battle Line in France. Therefore we submit under the circumstances we ought to have our rights.

We pray your Royal Highness to instruct the Indian Department at Ottawa, Canada, to reopen the said School at once, on condition we must be heard in the choice of a teacher, that is to say the Chief and Council.
and the Trustees, same as any school in the Country. We justly demand that the said clause be given to us as a right.

Trusting Your Royal Highness will give this petition your favourable consideration. We have been duly appointed by the Munsee Indian Council to act as this case in behalf of the Band.

God Save our King.

Sir,

I am enclosing a petition from the Munsees of the Thames re the re-opening of the school on their reserve.

It is to be considered that

(a) This band have no school, and many of them do not send their children to any school. A few go to Bear Creek school part of the time, but owing to a very bad, and untravelled road lying in between the two schools, it is almost impossible for them to go except in the summer months.

(b) The two bands do not work in as complete harmony as might be desired, and consequently the children do not get to school as often as they might.

(c) The distance is too great for several of the Munsees to go to Bear Creek school.

(d) I took the matter up with Mr. Inspector Johnson, who was very much in favour of the re-opening of the school.

With 15 children of school age, and 22 smaller ones to come along, it seems a shame that they should not be afforded some chance of receiving an education. Of course the question of where a teacher would board will be of some difficulty here; but one might board in Middlemiss, about 2 1/2 miles distant.

Your obedient servant,
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, August 13, 1918.

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the reopening of the school on the reserve of the Munceys of the Thames; apparently conditions have changed since this school was closed seven years ago, when there were only five children of school age in the section. Sir,

Re re-opening of the Munsee school.

In reply to the above mentioned letter, I beg to report as follows:

The chief, Mr. Samuel John, assures me that the band will be delighted to avail themselves of the privilege of school again; and that he will make it his business to "get after" those parents who are dilatory in sending their children to school.

As for a teacher's boarding place, I beg to enclose an application from Miss Mary McArthur of Middlemiss, who says that she would go home to Middlemiss in the summer months, and would possibly board with some Indian family in the winter. Mrs. Caroline Logan who lives very close to the school would possibly keep her, and her home is clean and tidy. I believe the Department is also in receipt of an application from Miss Helm of Appin, for the Oneida No. 3 school, which application might possibly be used in this case if Miss Helm has not yet obtained another school. Miss Helm's academic qualifications are very much better than Miss McArthur's, but Miss McArthur is a much more presentable girl, a qualification of no mean importance in choosing a teacher for small children.

With regard to repairs I would report as follows:

There are enough desks at present; they would merely need to fastened to the floor. The teacher's desk might be made to do for the present, although it is not very suitable. New blackboards are needed; a cupboard for books and supplies; and a new set of
Sir,

stovepipes; some repairs to the plaster; and the whole school scrubbed up. Together with this would be a whole set of the regular school equipment.

Outside, the closets need repairs and shields; and a small hole in the stone foundation needs repairs.

I believe that much of this work could be done by the Munsee people themselves. Many of them would help at a "bee", if a competent workman were put in charge to direct the work. I believe this would be a good plan, and no doubt would help to make the Indians more self-dependent, as well as reducing the actual cost of the work.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I have received my cheque for the past quarter and find that the bonus cheque has been cut to fifteen dollars ($15.00) and the salary cheque is one hundred and thirty seven dollars and fifty cents ($137.50). impossible at certain seasons of the year.

(2) There is no boarding house. The nearest being at Middlemiss, a distance of two and one-half miles. This makes it necessary that a horse and buggy has to be provided for, which is very expensive, besides a drive of this length twice a day is not very pleasant in the winter.

Therefore someone has to be provided to drive me to the school and return with the horse before nine o'clock and come after me at four o'clock. This would make a salary of seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) + the bonus of sixty dollars ($60.00).

Madam:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, to Mr. Agent McGookin, of Muncey, Ont. He has referred the inquiries you make concerning your salary and bonus to us. In reply I beg to state that in error your cheque for the September quarter read $137.50. The amount should have been $150.00 as you were being paid at the rate of $600.00 per annum. A cheque for the difference of $12.50 is being sent under separate cover.

Concerning your bonus, the flat rate of $150.00 per annum is now being paid to all teachers of Indian day schools. This is not payable quarterly, as formerly, but at the rate of $15.00 per month. There is but one teaching month in the quarter ended September; the result is that your bonus cheque for the September quarter was for $15.00. For the three succeeding quarters your bogus cheque will amount to $45.00, $15.00 for each teaching month.

You will understand, therefore, that you are being paid at the rate of $600.00 per annum, plus a bonus of $150, a total of $750.00.

I trust that this explanation will be satisfactory to you and I wish to assure you that an application for an increase in salary at the end of this academic year would be in order if your efforts as teacher at the Lower Muncey Indian Day School continue to be as successful as in the past.

I have noted the difficulty in connection with transportation to and from your school and would be glad to hear from you if this explanation eases your mind concerning financial matters.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

The unsatisfactory conditions and results of the day schools in the Cariboo agency necessitated an inspection and remedial measures. 162 children were enrolled during the past fiscal year and the average attendance, but 85 - a percentage of 46. The average salary we have been paying is $607. These facts are indicative of two reasons for the lack of progress, (1) bad attendance, (2) unqualified teachers.

In October I spent three days visiting the schools and the public school inspectors. The only really qualified teacher is Miss McDonald, at Oneida No. 3. Miss McArthur, at Muncey, is very successful and worthy of another trial. The other four teachers - Miss Brown at River Settlement, Miss Graham at Bear Creek, Mr. Doxtator at Oneida No. 2 and Mr. Fischer at Back Settlement - are unqualified and should be released at the first opportunity.

I returned to the reserve after a week-end at Moravian town and Malpole Island and met the Indian parents, the chiefs, and councillors, missionaries and others, at a general meeting in the Chippewa Council Hall. I explained that conditions were unsatisfactory and asked for the reasons. The parents and other Indians took quite an interest and were practically unanimous that there were but two reasons: (1) poor attendance, (2) unqualified teachers. The Chief, councillors and parents promised to do everything in their power to better the attendance and I assured them that the Department would install qualified teachers at the first opportunity. When pressed for my meaning in this connection, I explained that the teachers at the River Settlement and Bear Creek Schools could be changed practically at once, (end of the calendar year) as teachers could secure boarding accommodation in the vicinity, and that the Back Settlement and Oneida No. 2 tenors could be changed as soon as residences for qualified teachers could be provided.

I am including in the Estimates for 1925-26, as Important Day School Needs, a residence for the Back Settlement school, a residence (2 teachers) for Oneida No. 2 and No. 3. I also assure them that the only classroom building which was really unsatisfactory (that at Oneida No. 2) would be replaced at the first opportunity. A new building is now in the course of erection on a day labour basis.

I am arranging for better equipment in these schools and, in an effort to make them attractive, am providing some libraries and some articles for group games. At a later date it may be necessary to offer prizes for best attendance and to also organize the reserve into school districts so that a real interest will be aroused.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No.7-4-I of the 15th instant, regarding the services of Miss Mary McArthur, teacher at the Lower Muncey Day School.

I beg to say that while this teacher has given faithful service for the past eight years, I am of the opinion that it would be in the best interests of the pupils if a qualified teacher were appointed. Dear Mr. McGookin:

After the progress that has been made in the last three or four years in the development of the Caradoc Indian schools, I would be very disappointed if anything should happen to make them less efficient than they have grown to be.

The manifest interest you have taken in the schools which I have had the honour to inspect, has been no small factor contributing to their present state of efficiency. I think then, that it is only necessary to point out to you some of the ways in which the present situation may be improved, to secure your active cooperation in bringing about the necessary improvements.

The Lower Muncey school presents difficulties not present in the other schools on the Reserve: the isolated situation in the centre of the Reserve, the unsuitable character of the school building, the lack of necessary accommodation for the teacher, are all contributing causes making it a not attractive situation. Only someone possessed of the idea of being able to do something towards the uplift of the Indian people will persist in carrying on the duties of a teacher in this school, and this we have in the present teacher — she possesses the combination of good teaching ability, energy, and a desire to better the condition of the children in her charge. But it is not to be expected that these qualities, without encouragement, will continue to hold a teacher in a too-difficult position. The expense of getting to and from the school, besides the hardships entailed, is so great that she finds it next to impossible to continue the work.

I would then recommend that you use your best endeavour to get the Department to so increase her salary as to place her on the same basis as the other teachers on the Reserve.

I am satisfied you cannot do better than retain the services of Mrs. Phillips, if an increase of salary would do it. If you get an unsuitable person to take this position, one whose sole interest is money, you might better close the school.

Your obedient servant,

July 26, 1933.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

Replying to your memorandum of the 20th instant, I have to say that this Department has not during the past requested that teachers holding Interim Second Class Certificates for the province of Ontario give up duties upon the expiry of their certificates. Interim certificates, only, are granted teachers when they graduate from normal schools. These certificates are good for a period of four years, after which the Provincial Department of Education requires that teachers return to normal school for one year's study before their certificate is made permanent.

Miss Comfort, teacher of the Muncey School, obtained her Interim Certificate in the summer of 1928 and, therefore, under the Ontario regulations, the same has expired and she has no regular teaching certificate. In cases of this kind in Ontario Provincial schools, where teachers continue, they do so under authority of a permit from the Provincial Department of Education.

The last report received from the Provincial School Inspector stated that Miss Comfort was performing satisfactory service, and we have therefore taken no action to dispense with her services, although, under the requirements of the Ontario Department of Education, she would not now be eligible as teacher in a white school. We have never requested a teacher whose interim certificate has expired to return to normal school in order to obtain a permanent certificate.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

I wish to refer to your letter of October 9, wherein you outlined a policy in reference to the Back Settlement and Lower Muncey Schools. It is noted you had in mind, that at the reopening of the Back Settlement School, either Miss Comfort or Miss Howe would assume charge and that there would be a possibility of closing the Lower Muncey School. This question was again discussed during your recent visit, and I think it was understood that under existing conditions Miss Howe preferred to return to regular occupation. In this connection I have to advise that preparations are going ahead to have the basement of the Anglican Church made ready for the opening of school after the Christmas holidays, with Miss Howe as teacher.

This leaves the question of Lower Muncey and Miss Comfort. It was my impression that this school would close and the children would be given the option of attending Back Settlement, River Settlement, Bear Creek or be admitted to the Mt. Elgin Institute. Should this still be your policy, you will please confirm. It would also be appreciated if in the event of closing Lower Muncey, you have any suggestions in reference to Miss Comfort's services.

Mr. G.W. Down, Indian Agent, Muncey, Ont.

Re: Operation of Muncey and Back Settlement Schools

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 24th instant, in which you seek information in respect to the operation of the above-noted schools.

You may remember that it was my intention that Miss Comfort should take charge of the Back Settlement School immediately following the Christmas holidays and that the Muncey School should be closed. This decision was based on the assumption that Miss Howe would remain at your office as clerk. As Miss Howe, however, has decided to go back to her position as teacher at the Back Settlement School, I am not at all sure that the Muncey School should be closed. I am disposed to think that it might be in the interests of all parties concerned to permit it to remain open until the close of the present academic year. I have not in mind any school to which Miss Comfort could be appointed at that date. If you have not yet succeeded in securing a clerk would she be suitable for work at your office? You are more familiar with the pros and cons of the case and with local conditions than I am. You are authorized, therefore, to work out the best arrangements possible under the circumstances and send forward to us your final decision.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, November 9, 1942.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL

CARADOC:

SCHOOLS

There are six Indian day schools and one residential school - the Mount Elgin Institute - on this Reserve. Five of the schools were in operation at the time of my visit. A fully qualified, experienced teacher is in charge at each school, and I was favourable impressed by the courses of study provided for the pupils. The schools and school grounds were in no sense comparable to the schools of the Six Nations reserve. I noticed at the Muncey School, in charge of Miss B. Comfort, a tablet stating that this school was established in 1840, with funds collected in England by the Chief of the Band. This school was in a deplorable condition and had to be abandoned about two years ago. The pupils are now taught in the council chamber, which means that the members of the council have, for the time being at least, no place in which to meet. This has caused a certain amount of dissatisfaction. The old school should be dismantled and the lumber distributed to Indian for the repair of their homes, and a new school should be built.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Muncey, Ontario,
December 3rd, 1942.

R.A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. Welfare & Training, Ottawa.

In acknowledging your letter of November 27th, it is noted that the two schools, namely, Back Settlement and Lower Muncey, are to remain open immediately following the Christmas holidays.

I was rather interested in the later suggestion of your letter and have been giving it some thought. Miss Comfort would perhaps solve our problem, but before approaching her, I would like some definite proposal as to what the Civil Service Commission, the Department of Indian Affairs or the Ministers Office have in mind. Personally, I think she might fill the position with credit, but it would be hardly fair to ask her to accept such a position without giving her some assurance that her services would receive consideration in the recently advertised competition.

Todate, I have not been advised officially whether or not a suitable appointee applied and I do not appreciate the days ahead. Miss Howe has expressed a wish to terminate her engagement at this office on the 19th day of December. That however, is another matter, but I think the interpretation of your letter would suggest, providing other arrangements have not been made and providing Miss Comfort, would be willing to accept the office position that the Lower Muncey School be closed immediately following the Christmas Holidays.

I realize of course that the office appointment is a Civil Service appointment and perhaps not within your jurisdiction, but owing to the fact that the closing of a school is involved, you might discuss the matter with the officials directly concerned.

I shall await your reply with interest.

C.W. Down,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 9, 1942.

G. W. Down, Esq., Indian Agent, Muncey, Ont.

Your letter of December 3, 1942, addressed to Mr. R. A. Hoey, has been referred to me for attention.

So far as the competition held some weeks ago for the filling of the position of Clerk, Grade 2, at the Caradoc Agency is concerned, I have to advise you that no eligible list was established, and the matter of whether or not another competition widening the field of advertisement will be proceeded with is now under consideration by the Civil Service Commission.

I think, therefore, if Miss Comfort is willing to accept employment as Clerk at the Caradoc Agency, the Department will be very glad to accept her services and will recommend to the Civil Service Commission that she be appointed temporarily, effective January 2, 1943, as Clerk, Grade 2, at a salary of $1,060 per annum. If Miss Comfort accepts the offer of this employment, I would ask you to have her complete the enclosed application form, in duplicate, and forward both copies to this office as soon as possible in order that the matter may be taken up with the Civil Service Commission.

Should the Commission decide at a later date to advertise the position, Miss Comfort will have an opportunity to enter the competition. Please let me hear from you as soon as possible in order that action may be taken in the matter, both as to the Clerk and the suggested closing of the school.

Secretary, Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ontario.

SCHOOLS AND EDUCATION:

On the reopening of schools after the summer holidays, there was some doubt, owing to a scarcity of teachers, as to whether all schools would be open. This difficulty was solved by bringing in two of our old teachers and although I have not found it convenient to visit the several schools as often as I should have liked, I have to report, at this time, a very satisfactory teaching staff.

Mr. Doucet visited the Agency during the year and with him I visited the various schools. It was on a Sunday and I hope he enjoyed his communion. With the exception of Oneida No. 1 which is a new school, all, more or less, need repairs. Back Settlement, with its entire equipment was burned to the ground. This was quite a loss and disappointment to both teacher and pupils as some were studying for Entrance examinations. Arrangements have been made and the school has been reopened in the basement of the Anglican Church. Lower Muncey, with its small numerical enrollment has been closed and Miss Comfort who has taught the Muncey children for many years is taking over the position of clerk at the Indian Office.

Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Jackson,

I am coming today with a request for a little personal assistance from the Minister. Here are the facts.

We are experiencing very great difficulty in getting teachers for the Indian Schools. You know that where you have fifty or sixty boys it is impossible to have decent discipline unless at least you have one teacher who is a man. We have an offer of a teacher who is willing to go to Muncey. His name is Sam Dodds. He holds a first class teacher's certificate for Ontario. He was called up some time ago for military service and given the status of conscientious objector by the Tribunal. The Alternative Service sent him out to Banff to work but that, of course, has been closed out. He is now engaged in ordinary manual labour in the city. I think you will agree with me that it is a waste of good material to have a teacher employed as this man is just now in manual labour—not that there is anything wrong with manual labour but we need teachers. Under the circumstances, that he is a conscientious objector and that this status must be disclosed where any School Board would employ him because they would have to enter into a contract with Alternative Service, it is practically impossible for him to get a school.

We are willing to employ him at Muncey—indeed, we are anxious to have him. I am convinced that he will not, in any way, hurt the Indian children. He is a young man of fine appearance and excellent character. We have on a number of occasions been in touch with Selective Service in connection with the employment of conscientious objectors, and have received nothing but the most courteous consideration from them. However, I have reason to believe that Mr. Westman or Mr. McKinnon of the Department of Labour, who are the men in charge of this branch, would like to have a request from someone higher up to permit Mr. Dodds to be employed as a teacher at Muncey. If Mr. Crerar would be good enough, as he did on a previous occasion, to phone Mr. McNamara, asking that Mr. Dodds be made available for Muncey, I think the matter would be arranged in a minute. I hope Mr. Crerar will not be too busy to take two or three minutes of his time to do that for me. The School is to reopen on the first of September and action should be taken right away. It will be greatly appreciated if you will be good enough to do this for us.

The Muncey School was closed at the end of December, 1942, partly due to the fact that there was such a small number of children available. There was a phone call from the Minister's office this afternoon with reference to this school, and I am anxious to know if the situation has changed. Do you think this school should be re-opened? Of course, I realize that even if there are children available it will be difficult to secure teachers. However, I would like to have up to date information with regard to the situation at this point.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Reference is made to your letter of January 18th with regard to the Lower Neebing School.

First, you will recall that this section was closed due to the fact that there were only four or five pupils on the roll and no immediate prospect of increase.

Second, because the Council complained that the building, their council hall, was loaned for school purposes and that the people wanted it back for their meetings and social gatherings.

However, a check at this time reveals that the condition, as far as children old enough for school enrollment remains the same as 1942 with no immediate prospect of increase. The children who would ordinarily be attending this school, if it were open, are attending Red Creek school, which is approximately one mile from the Neebing School site and approximately one and one half miles from their homes. I do not think I would be justified in recommending that the school be reopened to accommodate four or five pupils. You must also keep in mind that the building is not a school. However, if for this it is necessary to reopen it, I will endeavour to make satisfactory arrangements with the Neebing Council, also try to secure a teacher, which in itself is a difficult proposition.

Ottawa.

I have your letter of the 19th instant, informing the Department that, owing to the serious illness of Miss Beulah Comfort, teacher of the Muncey Indian Day School, she has given up duties and that she will be unable to resume work for some time. The Department regrets the illness of Miss Comfort.

It is hoped that this arrangement will be temporary and that Miss Comfort will be able to resume duties in the near future.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the temporary appointment of Mr. Krinklaw, with salary at the rate of $35 per teaching month. Muncey, Ist March, 1929.

Attention of Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,

Sir,

I beg to enclose a letter received from Miss Buelah Comfort, who was appointed teacher at the Muncey Day School and took up her duties on the 4th of September, she taught until the 21st December when she was taken ill with appendicitis and has been unable to resume her duties since. It is hoped that she will be able to do so after the Easter holidays.

During the time Miss Comfort taught school, her services were entirely satisfactory. She took a real interest in her work and although only teaching for about fifteen weeks, the pupils made very good progress under her tuition.

Miss Comfort feels that she is entitled to some sick leave and I recommend, for your consideration and approval, that she be given one month's salary, this amount would greatly assist her in paying for operation and hospital account, and it would also add to her interest in her work. I will be glad if you can see your way clear to do this for her.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Muncey Indian Day School, states as follows:

"There is no well on the premises and for such a large school there should be water.

The school building would be better with a fresh coat of paint; it would preserve the building if put on at once.

One or two pupils have eye trouble. They should get treatment."

In connection with the well, I would draw your attention to your letter of March 2, 1923, in which you stated that the present arrangements would meet the situation quite satisfactorily if the well from which the supply is obtained were cleaned out and a cover put over it. I shall be pleased to hear whether this was done, and if it could not be satisfactorily arranged to obtain the supply of water required for the use of this school.

Regarding the Inspector's suggestion that the school building be painted, I have to request that you will state whether you would advise that this work be carried out early next spring. If so, please state the approximate cost of the labour and material, and how you would recommend that the work be done.

With reference to the pupils who require attention for eye trouble, you may arrange to have them examined by an optician and the glasses required supplied. No unnecessary expense should be incurred. It is considered that spectacles in steel mountings would be satisfactory. We note that only one or two pupils require attention. You should forward properly certified vouchers for the expenditure incurred in having the eyes of these children examined and the spectacles provided.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Replying to your letter No. 7-4-5 of the 27th ultimo with regard to the toilets at the Muncey Day School.

I beg to say that the closets are both placed on the South side of the school yard, about fifty feet apart; both closets are screened but both entrances face each other.

Removing the closets to another part of the yard is not recommended, there are public roads on the North and East sides of the lot and the Muncey Fair grounds on the West side; this part is low and quite muddy in the Fall and Spring.

The screen on the boy's closet might be turned round to face the West so that there would be more privacy than at present with entrances facing each other; this arrangement could be made at a cost of about $5.00.

There are no walks leading to the closets; an expenditure of approximately $25.00 would provide gravel paths for both closets and this is recommended for the Department's approval.

Fence wire tightened and about 15 new posts,

Original on File 7-4-6.

On the school premises, there is a frame building not originally intended for a school but a Mission. It is impossible with the present system of heating to properly heat this building, largely, on account of the high ceilings. The interior should be remodelled, if continued to be used as a classroom. The plaster is off the ceiling and the walls need redecoration badly.

There is a wood shed in good repair. Two closets situated in the very worst part of the yard, in a place often covered with water. They should be rebuilt in another part of the yard.

There is no water on the school premises and a supply of good pure water is necessary for the health and comfort of the pupils. There should be a good earthen ware tank in the school for holding the water, and individual drinking cups.

The school property could be made very much more attractive if rows of evergreen trees were planted along the north and west side of the school yard.

Sir:

With reference to your letter 7-4-5 of April 13th last relative to the renovation of the interior of Muncey Day School, I would recommend that the following work be done this Summer,

That owing to this class room ceiling being at least 18 feet high, that a false ceiling be put in at either 10 or 12 feet and to do this it would need 60, 2x4's, 14 feet long and 60 braces 1 x 4, 8 feet long, metalic ceiling could be put on the rafter, of which it would take 10 square at $5.00 a square. The plaster of the south wall to be removed and the whole replaced with gyproc. Two coats of muresco to be put on the whole interior, all walls and the ceiling.

Mr. Lucas of Glencoe, has estimated the cost of labour and material at $279.00 and I would recommend that he be given the contract at that price, with the understanding that he engage as much Indian labour as possible.

The roof of the school needs attention and this can be done by day labour and a good grade of elastic gum be put on around the chimney and ridge board, where it is now leaking. At a future date this steel roof should be painted to prevent rust. A gate is needed 10 feet long for the school fence a new floor put in the boys closet and locks on the closet doors and this should not exceed an additional $25.00 in cost and can be done by the Indians.

Miss Baird, Miss Comfort and Miss Howe, teachers on the Chippewa section of Caradoc Reserve, have requested that I take up with Dept. the building of car garages at each of their schools. In all three cases, their homes or boarding houses are miles from their school and it is necessary for them to use cars to get there and all day in all kinds of weather their cars must remain outside as there is no building to put them in. I understand a portable garage can be put up for around $100.00 and would ask your consideration of the erection of such a garage at each of the schools of the above-mentioned teachers.
Ottawa, December 14, 1929.

Sir:

Referring to your monthly report of inspection of the Bear Creek, Muncey and Rock Settlement Indian Day Schools in which you recommend that garages for the teachers' use be erected at each of these schools, I have to say that the Department will approve of the providing of garage accommodation at the Rock Settlement and Muncey Day Schools. If weather conditions permit, you may arrange for the erection of a garage of the portable type at each of these schools. You should see that the site selected in each case does not interfere with the playground accommodation or the general appearance of the school building. We note you estimate the cost of the erection of a portable garage to be approximately $100, but, if possible, to do so, they should be furnished at each school at less cost. The Department will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in the providing of suitable garage facilities for the teachers at both these schools. After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately.

Relative to the erection of a garage at the Bear Creek School, the Department does not consider that this is necessary at the present time. We understand that the teacher resides in the village of Middlesex, which is only a mile distant from the school, and that a car is not necessary to get to and from her school in any condition of weather.

The Department will expect to hear from you as soon as the two garages authorized above have been completed, with full particulars as to the type, cost, etc.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.

Sir,

I would beg to advise you that when accompanying Inspector McGookin to Lower Muncey Indian Day School, Caradoc Agency it was noticed that the fence around the school yard on one side was in a bad state of repair, also that one pane of glass 12" x 37½" was broken and needs replacing.

The roof of this school being of metal shingles has rusted considerable and to save it in future these shingles should be painted with a heavy coat of lead paint, and this could be done during the coming summer holidays. With reference to the fence repairs, I would advise that after making a guard fence on the entrance to a bridge on the Chippewa Reserve, I had about 12 rods of Page wire fence left and this wire could be used in the repair of the Lower Muncey school yard and only the cost of the work and a few staples would be necessary and I would wish to have your authority to do this work.

There is needed about six loads of gravel around the school building to fill the water holes that have been gouged out from rain from the roof; two loads of this gravel should be placed at the entrance to the outer houses of the school and the total of these repairs should not exceed $10.00.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Ottawa, May 27, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to the repairs required to the fence around the school yard and to the roof at the Lower Muncey Indian Day School, also regarding the gravel required around the school building.

Relative to the fencing, it is noted that you have sufficient wire on hand to make the repairs required. The Department will approve of you arranging to have the work done and also purchasing the staples required. You may arrange to have 6 loads of gravel spread around the school building and at the entrance to the out houses. You may also have the broken pane of glass replaced. After the above work has been carried out, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the repairs and materials.

Regarding the painting of the roof, I should be pleased to have a further report from you as to the work you would recommend be carried out and the approximate cost of same. I may say that our funds this year are extremely limited and only the painting required to prevent leakage or damage to the roof should be given consideration this summer. When we have your report as to the work to be done and the cost involved, further consideration will be given the matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ont.
Ottawa, July 8, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to the painting of the roof of the Lower Muncey Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging to have the roof of this school given two coats of a good grade of paint. The cost of the work should not exceed your estimate of approximately $50. You should arrange to purchase the paint, etc., required, and for the labour. In purchasing the paint, you should be guided by instructions regarding purchases in your Agency. It is considered that, if a good quality of a suitable paint is put on this roof, it would be satisfactory. This work should be carried out during the summer holidays, and, when completed, you should obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, which you should certify and forward to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

July 3rd 1931.

Sir,-

I would beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-4-5 of May 27th last with reference to some repairs to be carried out at Lower Muncey Indian Day school of this agency and with reference to the steel roof of this school, I would recommend that this roof receive two coats of a good quality paint, as a considerable number of the steel shingles are rusting and if these are not covered, they will soon cause leaks and do harm to the interior of this school.

I would be of the opinion that $40.00 or $50.00 would be a sufficient sum to do this work, but it is possible that the Department may know of some other way to coat this roof with some other material, such as a rubber gum or a solution of that nature and if so, I would be pleased to adopt your suggestion on this point, as no doubt you have had considerable repair work of a like nature on steel roofs of other buildings throughout the country.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Sir;-

I would beg to advise you that the following repairs are needed at the Lower Muncey Indian Bay School, and should be made during the coming Summer holidays,

10 rods of new 7 strand page wire fencing for school grounds.
10 new posts for fencing.
2 paned glass in frame for girls outhouse.
4 panes of glass for window in boys outhouse.
2 boards replaced on outhouse screen.
Small repair to floor in boys outhouse.
Repair look on girls outhouse.
2 window blinds for class-room.
1 pane of glass for porch window.

The fence at this school is badly in need of partial replacing and a number of new posts will be required. The panes of glass in the outhouses are continually be broken and replaced, and is the result of young hoodlums throwing stones from the adjacent road, which is always done out of school hours and which is likely to be done in future as long as there is glass for them to throw at. The teacher also claims this is the way the glass in the school porch was broken.

The total cost of the repairs at this school will run in the vicinity of $25.00 and it is recommended that these repairs be made.

There is at this school a three gallon crock water container and the tap of the container needs a little repair which can be done locally. There is no flagpole at the school and the teacher informs me that she has many times requisitioned for a flag with her school supplies and has never received one. A Union Jack flag 4' X 6' should be supplied to be hung up in the class-room.

Two flower beds and 18 shade trees have been planted since Mr. Sexton was at the school and were arranged for before his visit. Some small repairs are needed to the belfry at the school; 2 window locks to be installed; a new small wood gate to be built and the toilets are so old and have been repaired so often that I would recommend the building of two new ones and to use what material you can out of the old ones and that they be moved to a different location. The total expenditure at this school will be in the vicinity of $30.00 and the work should be done during the coming Summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Fyle References Re:
Breaking & Entering Lower Muncy Day School,
Muncy Reserve, Ontario.

Headquarters
(1) In the a.m. of the 25th instant Indian Agent A.D. Moore complained to this Detachment that the above noted School had been broken into.

Sub-Division
(2) A patrol was made to the school accompanied by the Caretaker, Lawrence Peters. Six panes of glass were found broken by stones being thrown through them; the lock on the teachers desk had been forced open and pencils which had been in the desk were found smashed in small pieces and strewn over the floor. Two cupboards had been broken into by prying the padlocks off.

Caretaker
(3) Questioning the caretaker as to how entry had been made he stated that the only suggestion he could offer was that the front door lock had been picked. He also stated that he had not visited the school for the past two weeks so that he was unable to say when the crime had occurred.

School
(4) The school is a very old one having been built in the year 1888 and the locks on the doors are very antiquated but at the same time very substantial. While the lock may have been picked open it is my humble opinion that the caretaker has inadvertently left the door unlocked on his last visit.

Building
(5) According to the caretaker there was nothing missing from the building and it would appear that whoever entered had done so for malicious reasons. Although a thorough examination was made there was nothing to indicate who was responsible for the act.

Residential
(6) Residents of the Reserve living in close proximity to the school were interviewed but no one had seen any persons around the school or heard the windows being broken. Willis Logan, Indian, stated that in his opinion the perpetrators of such an act would be George Snake who lives about three hundred yards from the School and Harry Mikokoman. These two young men, according to Logan, were continually causing annoyance to someone. Both these parties were interviewed and closely questioned but denied having taken any part in the crime.

Schools
(7) The Schools on the Reserve are kept under observation during the Summer holidays by this Detachment. A patrol was made to the school house in question on the 22nd instant and it had not been broken into at that time.

Expense
(8) There is no doubt but what this is the work of young boys or young men and was not for gain but merely out of mischief.

Memorandum: The Secretary.

You will note from Mr. Dudley's report hereunder that the Council Hall at Muncey was found to be in a very poor condition and that to repair the building would cost from $1,100 to $1,200, which expenditure would not be justified as it would be at best an old building requiring considerable upkeep in future.

Mr. Dudley suggested that the building at present used at Muncey as a Day School be used for the Council Hall, and that a new Day School be provided. The estimates for 1941-42, however, do not contain an item for a new day school at this point.

Mr. Dudley states that in its present condition the Hall should not be used for public meetings or dances, and that it should soon be closed to meetings of any sort. He does, however, state that it could be used for small meetings for another year or so.

Shall I prepare, for your signature, a letter to Mr. Moore advising him to instruct the Council to the effect that small private meetings can be held in the Council Hall, but that the building should not be used for large meetings or dances?

M. Walton.

Muncy, Ontario,
October 31st, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I would beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 7-4-5 of October 21st regarding water supply at four of the Indian Day Schools at Caradoc Agency.

In this connection I have made an inspection of the schools and the school grounds around each and would beg to report as follows:

Oneida No. 2 School

At the present time and during the past several years water for use at this school has been obtained directly across the road from an Indian named Abram Williams. The Department has been paying ten dollars for the privilege of obtaining water for the school for the school term of September to June of each year. Mr. Williams can continue to supply this water if reimbursed for it at the above price. Water is very scarce in the locality of this school and therefore, if a well is dug on the grounds there would be little chance of striking good water. A filtered well would be necessary. A well about 20 ft. deep and nine ft. in diameter could be dug. The water from the roof of the school would be carried into the earth troughing by means of a down pipe to the ground where it would enter a trench containing gravel to filter it. This trench would be connected with the well on the school grounds.

Bear Creek School

The water used at this school is obtained from a good spring which is situated in lands near the school. I understand that water has been obtained from this source for many years. At the present time there is a 12 ft. well located on the school grounds. In accordance with instructions contained in official letter of July 7th last, this well was cleaned out during the summer months and we were in hopes that water would come into the well which would be fit for drinking purposes. Apparently this well which was dug many years ago contains only surface water and was never used as the water was impure. The well does not contain any pump due to the fact that the well in it was never used. Since the well was thoroughly cleaned out in August, no water has yet come into it and therefore nothing further was done in connection with this well. In the first place it is too shallow and brickling in it is loose. Many bricks would have to be replaced and the well deepened and as good wells are very scarce in this neighbourhood it is very doubtful if water would be procured in this old well.

In view of the condition of this...........

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Bear Creek School - cont'd

In view of the condition of this old well it would involve considerable expense in repairing and deepening it and a new well could be dug here and the present one filled in. A filtered well the same as that described in this letter in connection with Oneida No. 2 School could be dug and if this were done no doubt a satisfactory water supply would be secured.

River Settlement School

At this school the water has been obtained from an excellent spring located near the school. Many Indians in the district surrounding this school obtain water from this spring. If the Department decide that a well is necessary on the school grounds I would suggest that a filtered well the same as described in this letter in connection with Oneida No. 2 School should be dug. Good wells are scarce in the locality of this school and it would be very unlikely that we would hit a good supply of water. Therefore a filtered well would be required.

Lower Muncey School

The water used at this school is obtained from a well located about three hundred yards from the school on the side of a public road. Many other Indians obtain their drinking water from this well in which there is no pump. In view of the fact that this well is located on a road some distance from the school lot I would not recommend placing a pump in it as it would be broken before long with numerous Indians using it. Therefore a well would have to be dug on the school grounds and in all probability we would not strike sufficient water in this area so that a filtered well would have to be installed the same as at the above described schools.

In accordance with the above it would, in my opinion, be necessary to install four new filtered wells if a supply of water for each school is to be obtained on the school lots. This would certainly entail a considerable expenditure as three of the schools have never been equipped with eavetroughing and this would first of all have to be put on. The only school which has eavetroughing on at the present time is the Bear Creek school. The estimated cost of completely installing four wells with pumps at these schools would be as follows:

Eavetroughing at 3 schools, approximately 250 ft. completely installed with down pipe $77.75

Digging four trenches, filling with gravel @ $2.00 per trench 8.00

Digging four wells each approximately 20 ft. deep and five ft. diameter (Indian labour at $2.50 per ft.) top on well included in this price $200.00

One cord of gravel delivered in small lots to each of the four schools 10.00

Three barrels of cement for top of well @ $2.50 8.40

(Cont'd)
Bricks for the four wells - 6400 @ $14.00 M $89.60

Four pumps (Beatty) 4" cylinder with 1½" pipe @ $15.00 each 60.00

230 ft. of facer board to attach eavetroughing 1" x 5" at $40.00 per M 9.20

In putting down four filtered wells at these schools the total estimated cost is $463.05 which includes all labour and materials.

It is my opinion that none of these schools are inconvenienced to any great extent because of lack of wells and this is particularly true at the River Settlement, Bear Creek and Lower Muncey Schools. There is an excellent spring very close to the River Settlement and Bear Creek Schools and there is a well on the side of the road near the Lower Muncey School. The pupils can easily carry one or two pails of water a day for use in the schools and I think it would be a good thing to have them carry the water to teach them to be useful. I understand that these schools have been procuring water in this manner for several years in the past and they could continue to do so in future.

The situation as far as water is concerned at the Oneida No. 2 School is more pressing as we have to pay ten dollars yearly for the water which the school obtains from Abram Williams and it might be a measure of economy to place a filtered well at this school and thus save this annual expense.

Of course, if funds are available, it would be much more convenient and proper to have filtered wells installed at each school but in my opinion neither the teachers nor the pupils at any of the four schools are suffering from lack of water.

I might add that if the wells are to be dug it could be done by an experienced Indian well-digger of this Agency and his price of $2.50 per foot is less expensive than it would be if we were to have it done by white men.

I trust that the information contained in this letter will be sufficient to enable the Department to arrive at a decision as to whether to install wells at these schools or not and I shall await your further instructions in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

M. W. McCracken, In Charge Caradoc Agency.
Ottawa,
November 6, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your very complete report regarding the water supply at four of the Indian day schools in the Caradoc Agency.

The Department is unable to provide, at the present time, the funds that will be necessary to have a well at each of the schools but, in view of the special conditions existing at the Oneida No. 2 School, you may arrange for a filtered well. I presume that the cost of this will be slightly over $100.00.

At the other schools the teachers should be encouraged to have the children carry the water to the school daily. This will not require any very heavy effort on their part and may be considered as a patriotic duty to relieve the Department of expenditure.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

OWING TO THE SHORT SUPPLY OF GLASS THIS SCHOOL MUST, OF NECESSITY, REMAIN CLOSED UNTIL REPAIRS CAN BE MADE. I WOULD ASK PARENTS AND ALL CONCERNED TO PLEASE CO-OPERATE AND IMPRESS UPON THE CHILDREN AND THOSE OF ADOLESCENT AGE THAT SUCH ACTS WILL NOT BE TOLERATED AND WILL ONLY MEET WITH PUNISHMENT.

INDIAN AGENT.
Acts of vandalism are always more or less present where juveniles congregate, but recent happenings at the Oneida No. 3 Indian Day School have demonstrated a determined act of wilful damage.

I have recently had some difficulty in locating and purchasing replacement glass for this school and, fortunately, before I could locate a man to put it in, some person or persons, adults or adolescents wilfully smashed every window in the school. The matter has been reported to the police and every effort has been, and is being made to determine the guilty party or parties, but to date we have been unsuccessful. Notices have been placed and residents in the immediate vicinity are angered by such acts and have promised to report any loitering on school property. Were it not for the fact that glass is in very short supply repairs could be made, but I have to close the school pending supplies.

I find it very difficult to keep pace with routine and the ever increasing Agency duties and such matters are extremely annoying. However, every effort will be made to secure glass and have the school reopened as soon as possible.
Ottawa, 26 October 1946.

Ottawa, April 25, 1938.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from Mr. J. H. Sexton, Inspector of Public Schools, in which he refers to conditions at the Lower Muncey School. Mr. Sexton's report reads in part as follows:

"Today the schoolroom was cold, dreary and uncomfortable (52 degrees Fah. at 1 o'clock). The teacher informs me that conditions have not been better during the winter, perhaps accounting for the prevailing illness in the section. There were only five pupils present today - Grades 1, 2, 6 and 7. These were not above the average in attainment, due to irregular attendance."

It is scarcely necessary to state that this report is wholly unsatisfactory. We have not at our disposal in the Training Division funds sufficient to pay for the operation of schools with an average attendance of approximately five. I am anxious, therefore, that you should make a thorough investigation of conditions at the Lower Muncey School. You should report to this Branch on the advisability of:

1. Closing the school and having the pupils transported to an adjoining school;

2. The removal of the pupils from the present building to the adjoining building which, I understand, was at one time used as a classroom;

3. The desirability and cost of making certain repairs to the present building, that will enable the pupils to undertake their studies in a classroom suitable for the purpose.

Your attention to this matter and a report to the Department at an early date will be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. R. A. Hoey.

I would acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 25th, File 7-4-6, dealing with the report of Mr. J. H. Sexton, Inspector of Public Schools, and concerning conditions at Lower Muncey School and would report as follows:

1. According to the teacher, the date of visit of the Inspector was one of the coldest days of the winter and a small attendance was the result. There is at this school 15 on the roll and on my day of visit, April 11th (being off duty during February and March) fourteen pupils were present and it is considered that this attendance is sufficient to keep this school open, although the enrolment does fluctuate due to the Indians moving around. This school also is the only one located on the Muncey Reserve of this agency.

2. The present classroom was considered best by the teacher, Medical Supt., Muncey Council, parents of children and myself because it was considerably smaller than the old classroom. The present building was the lesser of two evils and it would have taken much more to repair the old building than the present classroom which was a consideration in removing to the present building as well as size and continuation of use of the present building is considered most satisfactory in the long run.

3. Considerable repairs were made to the grounds and interior of the present classroom during the holiday period last Summer and in view of lack of funds then, repairs were kept to a minimum. Further repairs are necessary to the exterior of the building being the installation of some new window frames and sashes and also the purchase of storm windows and some additional siding to stop all draughts and when this is done it should make the building a quite comfortable and satisfactory classroom. As in past years, a recommendation will be made in June for repairs that can be done during the present Summer holidays.

The teacher also reports to me that the caretaker was very inexperienced during the past winter in her methods of firing a coal furnacette and that she improved considerable toward the latter part of the winter and this improved the heating.
conditions in the classroom. I would also inform you that both buildings, the old and the present classrooms, are very old and it will cost considerable in repairs in keeping them in shape and should an official of the Department visit at this stage or at an early date, I would deem it a favour that an inspection be made of the Lower Muncey River Settlement and Bear Creek Schools, all of which buildings are reported over 50 years of age and are going to cost the Department considerable for their repairs and upkeep in the future.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Greer:

Enclosed are my reports on the Indian Schools for this spring. A duplicate of this letter is also enclosed. It may be forwarded with the reports, if you deem it advisable.

The teachers on the reserve meet regularly to discuss methods and management. I regret that I have been able to attend only one of these meetings during the year. Ideas are exchanged, so the quality of the work is fairly uniform. Difficulties are solved and devices introduced. Next year they propose to meet with one of our township groups. It will be mutually beneficial. The one teacher who has not a certificate has given outstanding service this year. These meetings and a summer course last year have been very helpful to her.

As indicated on my reports, the traditional subjects of Reading, Writing, Arithmetic and Simple English Composition are learned well. The libraries of the schools need revision to enable the best work to be done in Social Studies. Generally, Art is excellent, Science and Health very good. This year a limited amount of Woodwork and Sewing has been introduced. This is very valuable, but I think that we should not look upon this phase of the work as vocational training. It does give pupils a very satisfying opportunity to demonstrate manual ability and makes school more attractive.

The teachers are gradually attempting the activity or project plan of learning. Possibly we should say that they are enlarging the application of this device for it has always been employed to some extent by good teachers.

I have been pleased to note that oral work has improved. Possibly the fact that I was a stranger last fall made the children very diffident about speaking.

All the ungraded schools have been provided with paper towels. Two of the buildings were painted and repaired last year and I understand that the other two will receive attention this year.
Mr. Greer - 2

Mr. Moore, the Indian agent, takes a keen interest in the schools and will look after this. I was pleased to note how the children are taking some interest in the care of the property. In one school each pupil has a little health kit—comb, tooth-brush, etc.—and uses it daily at the school.

The report on the Mount Elgin Institute is so complete that no reference to the building and accommodations is necessary here.

Trusting that these reports may be satisfactory,

I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

J. H. SEITON, ON MUNCEY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.
Report dated May 11, 1927.

The necessity of provision of some kind for a teacher's residence became very apparent during the past winter. At times, during the spring and fall, the roads leading to and from the school were almost impassable and, as there is no place in this part of the reserve where a teacher can find a suitable boarding place, it seems to me it would be wisdom to provide a residence.

I would suggest that one of the rooms in the school building proper be fitted for use of the present teacher, who is willing to occupy it during bad weather.
Ottawa, July 25th, 1927.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Lower Muncey Indian Day School, recommends that provision be made for living accommodation for the teacher. He states as follows:

"The necessity of provision of some kind for a teacher's residence became very apparent during the past winter. At times, during the spring and fall, the roads leading to and from the school were almost impassable and, as there is no place in this part of the reserve where a teacher can find a suitable boarding place, it seems to me it would be wisdom to provide a residence.

I would suggest that one of the rooms in the school building proper be fitted for use of the present teacher, who is willing to occupy it during bad weather."

I have to request that you will furnish a report regarding the Inspector's suggestions, together with your recommendations as to whether you would advise that any action be taken in the matter. The cost of any work which you would recommend be undertaken in providing living accommodation for the teacher should be stated. I shall be pleased to have this matter receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir,

In reply to your letter No.7-4-8 of the 25th instant reference to Inspector Sexton's recommendation that living accommodation for the teacher be provided at the Lower Muncey Day School.

I beg to say that in the winter months the roads leading to this school are very bad and it often difficult for the teacher to get through although the former teacher living at Middlemiss 3 miles distant used a horse and rig in the bad weather and attended the school regularly.

The suggestion that the class room be divided and fitted up as a residence has been discussed with Mr. Sexton, this suggestion has some merit but I am not prepared to make a definite recommendation that it be adopted. I think it would be advisable to have Mr. Orr look over the situation the first time he is in this vicinity.

The class room is 42 X 26 feet with a 15 foot ceiling, there is a teacher's room at the back 12 X 12 feet, the class room would be improved by having it made smaller and more compact and there would be sufficient room for living accommodation for the teacher, but whether the advantages in doing this would justify the expenditure or not is doubtful. Mrs. Phillips, the present teacher, would be willing to live at the school, but should another teacher be appointed in the future, it is very unlikely that she would care to live here alone as the school is situated some distance from a dwelling.
I would be glad to meet Mr. Orr at London and take him back, should you decide to have him look the situation over. I think this course would be advisable.

I have the honour to be, Sir.
Your obedient servant.

Another item of $500.00 is included in the Estimates for painting exterior and interior of the Lower Muncey Day School and for alterations to classroom, providing living accommodation for the teacher, as suggested in letter from Inspector Sexton to the Department, file No. 7-4-8, July 25th.

The cost of alterations would be approximately $300.00 and for painting the school and closets, $200.00. The teacher, Mrs. Phillips, is very anxious that living accommodation be provided, as the roads leading to the school are at times during the winter months almost impassable. The classroom is altogether too large for classroom work, and apart from providing living accommodation for the teacher, it would be greatly improved by being made smaller and more compact. It is 42 x 26 with a 15 foot ceiling. It is not up-to-date and is very hard to heat.
