There is a main school building, not Government owned, which is not, as it stands, suitable. In cold weather it cannot be kept warm and the children are not always comfortable. The building should be remodelled and a room furnished in it for a teacher's residence as there is no suitable place in the immediate neighborhood where the teacher can board.

If something of this kind is not done, it will be difficult to find a teacher to say in this school and there are a fine lot of pupils here to be taken care of.
Ottawa, January 28, 1928.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Lower Muncey Indian Day School in November, last, has drawn attention to the main school building. He states that this building should be remodelled as it is not suitable for school purposes and is difficult to keep warm. He recommends that a room be fitted up in the school building for the teacher's living quarters, as there is no suitable place in the immediate neighbourhood where the teacher can board.

In this connection I would refer you to your letter of September 30th, 1927, forwarding the estimates for your agency. I have to request that you will again draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next Spring, giving full particulars as to the alterations you would recommend be carried out in this building in order to provide better classroom facilities and also a room for the teacher's living quarters. It is noted that certain painting is required to the building, and in furnishing your report as asked for, you should also state definitely what painting should be carried out. The cost involved in any recommendation made by you in the alterations and in any other work should be stated. If, after your report is received in the Spring, it is decided to have the work done, it could be carried out during the summer holidays in July, next.

Indian day schools were in operation during the month but were closed on December 19th for the Christmas vacation. Sir,

Referring to file No. 18630, respecting Miss Mary Murray's application for an increase of salary as teacher of the school upon this Reserve, I beg leave to report as follows:

That the delay in attending to this subject was caused by my inability to obtain a Council meeting between the 2nd April and 19th Sept. last.

I have forwarded to you the minutes of Council of 19th Sept., and the following is a copy of them upon this matter.

The Agent read Departmental letter of 16th July respecting an increase in the salary of the Teacher Miss M. Murray.

Chief Councillor Wood thought that the salary Miss Murray was receiving was a good one and $50 more than she had received at the Hagersville School.

It was moved by Councillor Sterling seconded by Councillor Ymer and Resolved.

L. Van Koughnet Esq.,
Dep. Chief, Ind. Aff.
Ottawa
Resolved that the teachers salary be increased to $300 per annum provided the usual grant from the educational fund can be procured. Carried.

In favor of an increase of salary to Miss Murray. I find that her character is very good; that she taught for three years in one of the divisions of the Haginsville School; that she is very highly spoken of by the Haginsville School Board as a teacher and trainer of children; that since she has taught upon the Reserve, she has obtained the confidence of the parents and the almost loving respect of all the children; that since January 1888 the average attendance has increased from 12 daily to over 23, a remarkable increase; and that she is receiving $75 less than former.

From the foregoing Report I beg leave to recommend an appropriation from the "Indian School Fund of the Department" the sum of Fifty Dollars per annum to this Teacher Miss Mary Murray.

I do so, because $275. is good wages for an Indian Band to pay for a female teacher out of their own funds. Because by the peculiar tact and adaptation of Miss Murray these Indians are receiving about double the amount of education which statistics show heretofore existed, and because numerous teachers (mostly females) of Indians, are receiving from the Indian School Fund from $50 to $600 per annum.

I was hired by the year by the Trustees of the Credit School, without any agreement of dismissal or a month's notice. I did not agree to board close by the school. were I to employ the nearest Sordian and treat him as I have been treated I would be liable to the extent of the law.

In accordance with my instructions I herewith present a Return as to the relative standing of the pupils of the New Credit Indian School in the matters of proficiency, good conduct and regularity, in order to a just distribution of the prizes authorized by our local School By-laws, §§ 21-23.

In this Return no account is given of any pupils who have not attended at least one hundred days during the year ended September 30th, 1894. A few of these pupils stand well in their classes, and if they had been more regular could easily have won prizes. Parents and others interested can obtain all information in the power of the teacher to impart regarding the position of any pupil in any subject, by referring to the writer.

That care has been exercised to attain fairness in determining the relative standing of the pupils. The compiler of the return sincerely hopes that all who have any influence will support his decisions and endeavor to allay the jealousy and suspicion unavoidable so long as such a system of prizes remain in use. If the time-honored, meaningless, unprofitable charge of favoritism be circulated as heretofore in the case of former teachers, let it be remembered that if I were inclined to arrange matters so as to distribute the prizes according to my own interests, I would give them not to my supporters, but to the grumblers and malcontents whose support I wanted to obtain.

The relative standing of the pupils is founded almost wholly upon the average number of marks taken by each at the Quarterly Examinations, held March 30th, June 28th, September 29th, and October 4th and 5th.

It has unfortunately happened that the attendance has been rather small on all these dates, and some pupils of excellent class standing have been present at none. In cases such as these, when the highest marks obtained by the pupils present at the Examination was less than 60%, I have granted a Third prize upon general Class Standing.

Only three pupils in the Fourth Book attended over 100 days, so I have been obliged to count the marks obtained by this class in with those obtained by the Third Class.

This was the only course possible but even it is somewhat objectionable. For example, Jeffry McRoyall obtained 60% of the marks given for Fourth Book Geography, and if there had been another member in the class he would probably have obtained 1st or 2nd Prize. But several pupils in the Third Book obtained over 60% of the marks given for Third Book Geography, so Mr. Royall is thrown back into a comparatively poor position. However, as the Bye-laws require four members in each class to which prizes are given (§ 23) choice had to be made between this plan, which results in cutting down the prizes won by Fourth Book Students; and—of this course were not followed—the remaining alternative of letting them go without any prizes at all.

I would be pleased to explain my systems of marking etc., to anyone interested in the matter.

The case of Francis McRoyall is one to which I desire to draw special attention. This pupil, though of Indian blood, is through no fault of his own—not a recognized member of this Band. The money of his mother, brother, and sisters, however, helps to main-
tain the school, and her friends claim that she should on this ground be entitled to all the privileges of the school. As far as personal merit is concerned, the child deserves commendation and it certainly seems fit rather hardly visiting the sins of the father upon the children if she is to be denied recognition. If she be ruled eligible for prizes the chart marked "A" for combined Third and Fourth Classes is the one to be acted upon; if she be not considered eligible, chart B is to be used.

Effie Wood is a member of the Band who is in attendance upon the Haygreenville P.S. The number of days in the school year for the Haygreenville school differs from that in the New Credit School, but as she was absent only three days during the year when her school was in session, I have counted her attendance as equivalent to three days less than the school year recognized in the New Credit School.

When a "tie" has occurred in the number of marks obtained by prize winners, the prizes in question and the one next lower are to be added together and divided equally between the two. In the case of the prizes for spelling in the Part Second of the First Reader, the three prize winners all obtained equal marks so the total value of the prizes for this subject (viz., $1.00 + $0.25 = $1.25) is to be divided among them equally. This, I understand, is not the plan hitherto followed in such cases, but it is the only course founded upon justice and common sense.

Only one pupil who attended the full hundred days failed to win any prize. This is Johnstone.

It is of pressing importance that the prize money be paid promptly, as most of this money is expended on school clothes for the children.
and the writer is now close at hand. You will please represent these circumstances to the Department of Indian Affairs in the most forcible language and form possible, so that greater promptness may be avoided.

The Return re Relation Standing herewith presented, together with the foregoing explanations and comments is all respectfully submitted by

The Ruthlessmost obedient Servant,

Norman Ferguson Black,
Teacher R.C. Ind. School.

3. The Teacher agrees with the Trustees of the said Public School Trustees to teach and conduct the said school during the period of this agreement in accordance with the said Public School Acts and Regulations in that behalf.

4. This agreement is subject to the following conditions: (1) That the Teacher shall continue to be the holder of a legal Certificate of qualification as a Public School Teacher in Ontario during the period of this agreement. Hagersville Nov 19th 1903
Sir,

At a representative and well attended meeting of this Band held yesterday afternoon in the Council House.

It was moved by Chief Mr. J. King seconded by Joseph Lefebvre.

Resolved that all children living upon this Reserve be allowed to attend our school free.

A standing vote was taken when all members present with two or three exceptions stood up in favour of this resolution. John Chisholm was the only member of the Band who voted contrary.

I was instructed to submit this resolution to the Department for their consideration and approval.

The question was discussed at length and the following are some of the reasons advanced why the resolution should be adopted:

1. There is plenty of room in the school for all children on this Reserve. It costs no more for fuel, caretaker or teacher, outside buying their own books. The teacher says she would rather have them attend, as 30 or 40 scholars together make more progress than one.

The Secretary

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
Our third chief number would be a number of our children attending a residential school adjoining this Reserve at the Mohawk Institute at Brantford free of charge.

The majority of those members attending belong to the Brant family who have been closely identified with this Band by reason of having always lived among them and still occupy land upon this Reserve; they are also closely related by marriage.

Of the most important reason is that according to the terms of settlement between the Mississaugas and the Nations in 1800, the land was to be occupied in common and that members of either Band may purchase or from the other the right of occupancy, so there will be more or less intermarriage of the two Bands, so that it appears to be only fair to attend each other's school in common.

I am well aware that the Rules and Regulations of the Band say these Members shall pay fifty cents per month.

The members present were of the opinion that these Rules & Regulations should be revised and amended. If you have not had a supply printed from the copy I sent you on Feb. 10th we would respectfully ask permission to do so.

Your obedient servant,

W.C. Van Loan
Indian Agent

Secretary Dept. Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

At the regular meeting of our Council in January a resolution was passed regarding the trustees of our school to run the school according to the by-laws regulating same and acting in accordance with the resolution. I asked the senior trustee to notify the teacher to notify our members that they would be required to pay $5 a month on account as provided in by-laws and then non-members took their children away.

After sometime considerate of that the senior trustee, Mr. McDougall, and allowed the non-member children to attend school free of charge. I am one of the trustees and was not notified in case of any business trustee should have done nothing. Otherwise I think the matter would not be legal. On the 2nd next a public meeting of the Band was held and at this meeting a resolution was passed for the effect that all non-member children be allowed to attend our school free. This I think is wrong as I do not think said meeting had the power legally make such a rule. As I claim the trustees have full power.
To run the school in accordance with by-laws, as the Mississaugas built the school and furnish equipment and teachers; I think it an injustice for outsiders to be allowed free use of it and would ask the Dept. to protect in same. Would also ask the Dept. to send one copy of by-laws also to confirm Agent as to the powers of Trustees. Although I have asked the Senior Inspector Dault, Notice to call a meeting of the Board he has not done so. Would be pleased to get instructions from the Dept. as to how the trustees should act.

Yours ever,

John Sheehan

Sir,

Enclosed find school report from Miss L. Mitchell teacher of the New Credit School for Indians ending Dec 31st 1909. Also request for teachers salary and school materials.

The teacher notified the trustees that unless her salary was increased to $400.00 a year they would have to look for another teacher. The trustees refused to recommend this increase, and she has taken another school for $25.00. They then requested me to advertise for a teacher in the daily paper which I did, and it answered three times.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant advising the Department of the resignation of Miss Mitchell, teacher of the New Credit School, owing to the refusal of the trustees to increase her salary to $400.00 per year.

In reply I beg to say that you should have advised the Department that Miss Mitchell made a request for an increase, as it reserves the right to dismiss or engage teachers and also to deal finally with all questions of increase in salary. The Department considers that a mistake was made by the Indian trustees in refusing Miss Mitchell this increase as it is a very difficult matter at the present time to secure the services of a qualified teacher.

The Department should also have been consulted before any advertisement was placed in the paper for a new teacher.

It is most desirable that a qualified teacher should be obtained for this school, if possible, and this cannot be done unless a more liberal salary is paid. You did not state the salary that you offered, if any, in your advertisement in the Globe.

The Department cannot approve of bringing a young

Sir,

There may be reasons for which a child should be excused from attending the school over and above those enumerated in clause 17 of the regulations and in that case it will be for you to exercise your discretion. 1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.

6. The class standard of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular standard. The standard course for each class will be found on the back of the Daily Register and is to be followed.

10. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days' attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.

11. No teacher's salary will be paid until this Return has been received by the Department.

12. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.

13. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.

In February, last, Mr. Agent VanLoon stated that he considered that it would be in the best interests of the New Credit School if the services of a qualified teacher could be secured after the summer holidays, as they had not had one for the past five years. It was his opinion that one could be secured for about what we were then paying. On the strength of this letter Mr. VanLoon was requested to inform the teacher, Mr. Cragg, that his engagement would expire on the 30th of June, last, and if a qualified teacher could be secured the Department would not re-engage him. The Agent was also instructed to communicate with the Public School Inspector with a view to securing a qualified teacher for this school. In a letter dated June 12th the Agent stated that he wrote to the County Inspector, but got no answer, and that in his opinion the only way to get a teacher is to advertise in the Toronto papers.

An
An advertisement was inserted in The Mail and Empire for a teacher with Normal training for this school. The salary offered was $500.00 per annum. The only application received is from Mr. C. M. Ross of Jarvis, Ont., who claims to be the holder of a Third class normal trained certificate with one year's experience in the Model School affiliated with the Normal School at Hamilton. He asks for a salary of $550.00 a year. Mr. Vanloon forwards testimonials from J. G. Foote, Methodist Minister at Jarvis and Dr. Howell of the same place as to his character. He has apparently never had charge of a school and his qualifications would hardly entitle him to more than an initial salary of $500.00. Mr. Vanloon states that Mr. Ross would like to know as soon as possible whether his services are accepted, as he intends to apply for another school.

Before accepting the services of Mr. Ross, I wish to mention to you that Miss Gertrude Lawrence, who taught most successfully in the Assiniboine Day School for the past six years, when tendering her resignation, stated that if a vacancy should occur in any of the Indian day schools in Ontario she would like to be considered as an applicant. A letter has been received from her dated the
the 20th instant, in which she renews her application for re-engagement in Ontario. Miss Lawrence is an experienced teacher and was most highly recommended when she applied for the Assiniboine School. I think the Department would be fortunate if it could again secure her services. Her present address is 12 Delaware Ave., Toronto, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I wish to resign my position as teacher in the school here. It seems that it is not going to be possible for me to get a boarding place nearer the school, and as I explained to you on Friday, I would not consider remaining where I am. I have not spoken to Mrs. Grant about it myself, but Mrs. Cragg and Mrs. Flowers both tell me that she has said that she could not take me in and of course would not attempt to force myself upon her.

It will, I suppose, be necessary to give the Department a month's notice of my intention to leave, but if it is possible,

Sir:-

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, informing the Department that Miss Lewis, teacher of the New Credit Indian Day School, requests that her salary be paid monthly instead of in quarterly installments.

In reply I beg to say that, owing to the large number of teachers, it is the policy of the Department to only pay salaries at the end of each quarter, upon receipt of quarterly returns, and we are not prepared to make any exception in the case of Miss Lewis. We will, however, allow her an advance equal to one-half of her quarterly salary, upon a request being made for the same. It is hoped that this arrangement will be of assistance to Miss Lewis in her financial affairs, and that she will feel satisfied to remain, if an advance is made her each quarter.

With reference to the case of the Six Nations' schools mentioned by you, I beg to say that these schools are conducted under a school board. The grants from the Department are forwarded quarterly, and from this the board arranges to pay the teachers monthly. The bonus, under the terms which it is paid, can only be paid quarterly.

You should advise Miss Lewis accordingly, and inform the Department as to whether the above arrangement for the granting of an advance will be satisfactory to her.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The attention of the Department has been drawn to the case of several of the pupils of the New Credit Indian Day School who are very irregular in their attendance. The names of these children are Ruben Herkimer, James Sault and Frances Laforme.

In the case of the first named, Ruben Herkimer, this boy remains away from school whenever he chooses. He is stated to be 12 years of age and is absent about two-thirds of the time. The mother of Frances Laforme keeps this girl away from school without any reasonable excuse. The home surroundings are stated to be deplorable.

It is considered that it would be advisable to take the necessary action to have these children placed in a residential school. If the parents refuse to sign applications for their admission, steps will be taken under Section 10 of the Indian Act to have them committed to a residential school. If these children are Protestant, they could be placed in either the Mohawk Institute or the Mt. Elgin Industrial School.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding this matter and your opinion as to whether you would recommend that the action mentioned above be taken. As an example to the other Indian parents, and in the interests of the children themselves, it is thought that this would be the best course to adopt.

Dear Sir,

Some time ago I made a personal application for the position of teacher for the Indian School on the New Credit Reserve near Hagersville, Ont. The Indian Agent, Mr. Van Loon, informed me that he had left the matter with Mr. Mitchener, Inspector of Schools, at Cayuga and I went down and interviewed him. He expressed himself as quite satisfied that I should have the school, but today, after an interview with Mr. Van Loon, he phoned me that they were leaving the matter with your Department, consequently I am addressing you.

I hold a second class non-professional certificate and held a third class
professional one, having graduated from the Hamilton Model Training School some years ago.

After teaching for five years in public schools of Brant County, I went to teach at the Ontario School for the Blind, at Brantford and spent nine years there during which time I allowed my professional certificate to expire as I did not need it while teaching there. For the past four years, I have been teaching on the Six Nations Reserve at Brantford and the letter enclosed from Lieut.-Col. Morgan speaks for itself.

I am enclosing testimonials from Mr. T. W. Standing, Public School Inspector for Brant, and from Mr. Noah Kanevery, trustee in charge of No.'s 4 and 7 schools on the Six Nations Reserve.

Although I have not had full Normal School training, you will, no doubt, agree that my experience in teaching in both the Public and Indian Schools, more
than offsets this disadvantage.

If appointed to the position, it shall be my earnest endeavour to carry out my duties with satisfaction to all concerned.

Yours truly,
Daniel T. Green.

Sir,

On the evening of October 13th, Mr. Lloyd Martindale, teacher of the New Credit school, called on me on his way to the school teachers convention to be held in Caledonia and stated he had accepted a position in the Civil Service and was to report at Port Colborne at once, and would send in his resignation, but would endeavour to hang until we could find a satisfactory teacher.

He called again on Saturday evening and handed me his resignation, he also stated he had secured a qualified teacher to take over the school and would report here on Monday morning. I called up the school Inspector, Mr. Mitchener, he stated Mr. Martindale had consulted him in the matter and thought the arrangement would be satisfactory.

To-day the new teacher arrived, he is a young man twenty years of age, he comes from Elmira, Ont., he holds a first class certificate and has taken a course at the University of Toronto. I like the appearance of him and feel sure he will be satisfactory. His name is Harold Clinick.

I will enclose Mr. Martindale's resignation as he taught for half the month I suppose he will be entitled to pay for the time he taught.

Hagersville Nov. 15th 1926

Sir,

Before the council meeting yesterday I visited the school (New Credit) and there were fifteen pupils present, which I considered a fair attendance when the roads are in such bad state.

We have a splendid teacher and if the pupils will attend regularly they are sure to make good progress.

Now I propose to make an example of two of worst delinquents. Reuben Herkimer lives in the second house east of the school, less than 100 rods from the school, has a son nine years of age, who has been very irregular; he has been warned by the truant officer, after a warning he will only attend for a day or two and then quit, when I spoke to his father his only excuse was that he had no shoes, although the father has a good 100 acre farm and older boy about 15 or 20.

Wm. H. Laform lives on the S. 1/2 of Lot 5 Con. I. Tuscarora. His son only attends occasionally although he has been warned by the Truant officer and myself, his mother simply says the boy is sick, but they do not get a doctor's certificate, and the boy is able run around the neighbourhood.

The Mounted Police ride past both places occasionally. I want them to notify the parents that unless they get a doctor's certificate, the boys must go to school and if they fail when they call again they will be taken and placed in an industrial school where they will attend. This would have a good effect on all parents and pupils on this reserve.

I do not know if the Police would take orders from me or not, they say they have nothing to do with this reserve. If not I will ask Col. Morgan give them the order.

Your Obedient Servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, November 20, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, relative to utilizing the services of the mounted police in notifying the parents who neglect to send their children of school age regularly to the New Credit Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that in the case of the two delinquent parents, viz., Reuben Harkimer and Wm. H. Laform, who have been repeatedly warned by the truant officer to send their children to school, and who have neglected to do so, you may request the officer of the mounted police in charge of the detachment at Ohsweken to notify the two parties named that their children of school age, who are in good health, are to attend school regularly each day it is open. If the parents refuse to send their children after they have been duly notified by the police, steps should be taken to have the children placed in an Indian residential school, but before doing so, you should report the facts to the Department and receive instructions as to the school to which they should be sent.

You may show this letter to the mounted police as your authority for asking their services in investigating and notifying parents of delinquent children. If the police will not act on this notice from you, you may request Colonel Morgan, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, to request them to investigate and give the parents notice that their children must attend school regularly.

I shall be pleased to hear later as to the result of any action taken by the police.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Mr. Senn:

I wish to refer to recent conversation in regard to salary paid Winifred Bachar, teacher of the Mississaugas of the Credit Indian Day School; also salaries paid teachers of the Indian day schools on the Six Nations Reserve.

Mr. Bachar was appointed teacher as from September first, 1931, with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month. This salary has been subject to the 10% cut since April first, last. In compliance with the Salary Deduction Act, 1932, and regulations of the Treasury Board, it is not possible to make any increase in salaries during the present fiscal year. No exception can be made to either grant an increase or to exempt any salary from the 10% cut. It is considered that the salary paid Mr. Bachar compares favourably with that paid teachers in the surrounding rural white schools having similar qualifications to his and as large an enrolment of pupils as at the New Credit School.

Regarding salaries of teachers on the Six Nations Reserve, previous to April first, 1929, all these salaries were paid from the funds of the Band. Since that date, however, the salaries of the Six Nations teachers have, the same as in the case of all teachers in the other Indian schools in Canada, been paid from Parliamentary Appropriation. The

M. G. Senn, Esq., M. P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ont.
salary of the Six Nations teachers was set by the School Board at the time payment was made from their funds, and the same scale has been continued. A teacher having at least second class professional qualifications receives a minimum salary of $1,000, which, after a year's service, is increased $50 per annum until the maximum, viz.: $1,200, is reached. During the present fiscal year, however, all salaries of teachers on the Six Nations Reserve are subject to the 10% cut, and no increase was granted. Indians are engaged as teachers as far as possible. When the services of an Indian teacher, who has not the minimum qualifications, are engaged, the salary allowed in such cases is at the rate of $900 per annum. I may add that the Six Nations are the only Band in Canada which have their own School Board. While all salaries and appointments made by the Board are subject to the approval of the Department, yet, owing to circumstances on this reserve, we rarely take exception to the appointment of a teacher made by the Board or in salary which, as stated, was set when salaries were entirely paid from the funds of the Band.

In schools other than the Six Nations, teachers are engaged at a remuneration based on qualifications - the salary paid depending more or less on the supply of teachers.

Yours very truly,

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

New Credit Agency.

I inspected this agency on the 19th instant and beg to submit the following brief report:

The Indian Day School is being conducted in the Council Hall since the burning of the school building a year ago. The present arrangement is working very well. Some minor changes were made in the room and a new and larger stove provided making it quite suitable for classroom work. Attendance has been very good up to the present and the pupils are making headway in their studies. They have all been vaccinated up to date and receive a daily issue of Cod Liver Oil which Dr. McCracken states had had a most beneficial effect upon their health.

The Foundation.

To be built of good full sized building stone, laid in good mortar. That below the ground in good rubble masonry and in random covered work neatly adjacent above the ground. The walls on both sides are to be worked fair and smooth.

**Platform**
The platform to be built of the same material as the steps, supported on 2" x 8" joists, all to rest on cedar posts.

**Newel Posts**
Provide and fit 6" x 6" turned newels to each pair of steps as shown in the plans, and fit-in a cast-iron newel hand rail and balusters. Hand rail to be 3" x 4" balusters 2 1/2" x 2 1/2" all of oak.

**Porch Roof**
Provide 2" x 8" joists and place 15" apart, and cover with 1/4" flooring, matched with 3" fall to the back inside corner and covered with best 26 gauge galvanized.
galvanized iron will make a tower with flat walls, and the seams will be closed. The roof to have an iron cresting of approved design, as shown in plan.

Belfry

The belfry to be 5' x 5', placed on building as shown in plan, and made in detail and proportion, the same as that on the Council house.

Earthing

Provide and fix in position 15" gut earthings to the main building O.G. in style, with two down pipes at the rear end 3" in diameter, also two small down pipes for portholes, 2" in diameter.

Black Boards

Provide material to bath and plaster a black board 3' x 3' and placed as directed by the Council. The mortar to be made 1 part cement, 1 part Portland cement, 2 parts lime and 2 parts sand after being put on to be well floated up, to be perfectly straight. The 2nd coat to consist of 2 parts Portland cement, 1 part lime and sufficient...
Sufficient plaster to make it neat for finish, can must be taken to have a good amount to our face and the east coat colored black with but Campbell.

Painting:
Provide and prime with the best white lead and oil all of the windows, door frames, doors, and sashes.

Glazing:
Provide and glaze in each sash, with first quality double three diamond star glass. Can must be taken to have the glass well fitted in pretty points.

General Conditions:
Everything is to be provided to make the School House complete without extra charge, and the whole work is to be executed in a good sound and trademanslike manner, subject to the approval of the Inspector's Architect, the Agent, and the Council, who shall be the judges of the work, and its correspondence with the Drawings and Specifications.

SPECIFICATIONS.

For the Erection of a School House upon the Reserve of the Mississaugas of the Credit Township of Tuscarora, County of Brant, Ontario.

General.

The building to be a frame, with red brick veneering, trimmed with white brick; having two porches and a bell tower.

The main building to have an inside measurement of 35 X 20 feet; the porches inside measurement of 6 X 8 feet. The walls of main building to be 14 feet high.

Excavations.

The excavations for the foundations of the walls of main building and porches to be not less than 3' deep, and for the centre or dwarf wall not less than 1' deep.

The Foundation.

To be built of good full sized building stone, laid in good mortar, that below the ground in good rubble masonry and in random coursed work neatly jointed above the ground. The walls on both sides are to be worked fair and smooth and to be pointed above ground with blue mortar, with a neat white joint, and the joints are to be neatly struck with the trowell. The footing of the wall to be not less than two feet in width and to slope inwards to 18 inches as shown upon plate No. 1.

The foundation at the places (indicated in the plans) for the chimneys to be as much wider as is necessary to support said chimneys. The mortar is to be composed of well burnt lime 1/3 and

(2)
and clean sharp sand 2/3, well mixed with water in due proportions. The centre foundations to be 1 foot in width at the top, one foot in the ground and two feet above ground, of good rubble masonry. The whole stone work to be well bedded and bound together in a good, sound, tradesmanlike manner.

Brick Layers.

The bricks are to be good, hard, sound, fresh, well burnt red and white, of even surface and even colour. They are to be well bedded and bevelled at every course, and the front to be neatly jointed.

They are to be firmly spiked every fourth tier, the brick laid 8 courses to the 23°, and the walls above the plates are to be filled to the level of the roof sheeting. The corners are to be of white brick, and a white brick belt around the building and porches as shown in Plans Nos. 1 and 2.

Chimneys.

The chimneys are to be built from foundation to topping; the one at the rear of the building to have two flues, one for smoke and one for ventilation, one side chimney to have a smoke flue, the other a ventilation flue.

The openings into the building to be made according to the direction of the Council. The smoke flues to be well and thoroughly plastered upon the inside, wall in, and bed in mortar all the brick work between door and window sills and frames, and have the whole complete in every respect. All necessary stove pipe or ventilation collars and stoppers to be provided and properly placed.

Stone Sills.

Provide properly dressed stone sills for the two porch doors.

(3)
to be 6" X 12" and 6" longer than the openings.

Carpenter and Joiner.

Joists, Ground Floor.

The Joists for the ground floor to be 2" X 8 inches, to rest upon sills upon the foundation 2" X 6" which have been properly bedded with mortar. They shall be placed 18" apart, centre to centre.

Studding Rafters, Collar Beams, and Suspending Posts.

The Studding is to be 2" X 4" the upper joist 2" X 6". The rafters 2" X 6" and the collar beams 6" X 2". The suspending posts 6" X 1" to be placed 18" from centre to centre, all this material must be of good sound pine and free from loose knots. The rafters are to be properly notched and spiked down, and the whole framework securely spiked and nailed upon a XXXXX 4" X 2" X 16" plate above the brick work.

Sheeting.

The main building and porches to be covered outside the studding with good, sound 1 inch sheeting.

Roofing.

Roof Sheeting.

The roof to be sheeted the same with good, sound one inch pine.

Shingles.

To be 3" laid 4 1/2" to the weather and bedded in 1/2 inch of mortar or laid upon tar paper, as the committee may direct, two or more nails to each shingle.

Gutters.

The cornices of main roof to project 4" from the brick work horizontally with the proper fascia boards and mouldings as shown by Drawing No.

(4)
Saddle Boards

The ridge of roof is to be covered with 2 1/2" rods to be carefully laid on saddle boards less than 6 inches wide.

Arched Openings.

The openings from the main building into the porches to be 4' 6" wide 7' 6" from floor to crown of arch.

They are to be properly arched and neatly eased in, with good appropriate moulding, the frames to be strong and substantial and tenoned with an oak mill 3 inches thick, and all tenons to be painted with white lead before fixing.

Flooring.

The flooring to be well seasoned matched pine flooring 1 1/2 inches thick 4 inches wide closely laid and blind nailed to each joint and to be dressed after being laid, and to be free from shakes and loose knots. The floor of the teacher's dais or platform to be 8 feet wide, to be placed upon 6" X 2" joists 1' 8" apart upon the floor of the school, which, under the dais, may be rough undressed flooring, the platform floor to have nosing and proper moulding.

Wainscot.

Specifications for Painting the Exterior and Interior of the New Credit School House, on the Mississaugas of the Credit Reserve,

1. The contractor is to provide all material, of every description and also all tools, labour, and scaffolding & necessary for the completion of the work.

2. PAINTING:

Paint all exposed exterior and interior woodwork and ironwork two coats of lead and oil, tinted as directed by the Agent in charge.

3. CLEANING OF:

If there is any loose or dead paint adhering to the woodwork, this is to be carefully scraped and sandpapered smooth and any live knots or pitch showing on the surface to be carefully covered with best quality of shellac.

4. MATERIAL:

The lead to be used to be the best Canadian white lead (ground in oil), pure boiled linseed oil, and pure spirits of turpentine as dryer.

5. The first coat to have sufficient oil to thoroughly penetrate the wood and bind the lead and paint thereto; and when dry to be finished with a heavy flowing coat of lead and oil of tint as required.

6. All work to be done in a good and workmanlike manner and satisfactory to the Agent or Inspector, and fully completed before the fifteenth day of August 1910.

Sir,

When visiting the school yesterday I discovered that the bell had fallen down in the belfry and broken the crank. It will cost three or four dollars to have it put in its place again; it will be necessary to put new pieces of timber across the bottom to carry the bell.

This should be attended to at once; the trustees reported the matter to me, and I have no doubt but what the council of the band will approve of it.

When the school house was erected twenty-two years ago an pine floor was put down; it is now badly worn and it is almost impossible to keep it clean as it is very uneven and worn through in places; a new floor should be laid of maple. New water closets should be built also; the present ones were brought there from the old school building stood where and must have been built forty years ago; they are in a very bad condition. I will bring the matter before the council at their next meeting.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Specifications of material and labour required for the erection and completion of two water closets at the school house on the New Credit Reserve, at New Credit, Ontario.

Also a new floor to be laid in the school house.

The Contractor is to provide all material and labour and do everything necessary to complete said buildings and lay the new floor in the school house.

The closets are to be five feet wide, seven feet long, and six feet high with ridge roof and built according to a plan prepared by the Agent for the reserve.

The sills are to be 4 x 4, joist 2 x 4, and 15" center to center corner and door posts to be 2 x 4, with plates of 2 x 4 well spiked on, girts 2 x 4 not more than two foot a part, rafters 2 x 4, and not more than two foot a part, well and firmly nailed together at tops and to the plates.

Floor to be of sound, seasoned pine or spruce, tongued and grooved and nailed to every joist.

Outside walls to be covered with sound dry pine, boarded up and down nailed close together and battened.

Roof to be covered with sound pine or hemlock sheeting well nailed to every rafter and covered with XXX B.C. shingles laid 5" to the weather, not less than two nails in any shingle.

To have proper ridge boards, one ventilator on each building 6" square. Doors to be made of sound matched pine lumber hung with 6" hinges and suitable thumb latch.

To have suitable cornice to project 5" all round.

Both buildings to have an 8" circle opening in each gable, near the top to let in light. To be set on stone butments true and level, over trenches 2' wide 6' long and 3' feet deep, and left complete in every particular and satisfactory to the Agent or Inspector. Floor in school house and porches to be covered with sound seasoned, tongued and grooved maple flooring 7/8" thick and not more than 4" wide, well nailed every 18" and to have new round all round the edge of floors. Seats to be taken up and replaced as directed, the whole to be left complete and satisfactory to the Agent or Inspector, and completed during Easter holidays in April 1914.

Haywood March 23rd 1914

W.T. [signature]

SPECIFICATIONS FOR CONCRETE PLATFORMS, STEPS, and WALK, at the School house and Council house on the Mississaugas of the Credit reserve.

All the work and material to be in accordance with the plans and specifications prepared for the same. Anything omitted but necessary for the satisfactory completion of the work must be provided by the contractor without extra charge.

The Contractor must clear away old steps and platforms and all rubbish and level the ground for the platform and steps. There must be two steps on two sides of both platforms at the entrances to the school house, and two steps on three sides of the entrance to the council house.

All platforms and steps to be true and level, except one fall half inch to the foot fall to the front to allow water to run off. The Contractor to do what excavating is necessary to make the walk to the school entrances true and level and not less than six inches thick in any place, the walk to be cut in blocks not more than four feet in length, to be three feet wide from road to about four feet from steps when it is to be extended to make it six feet at the bottom of the first step.

The concrete is to be composed of one part of Portland cement, two parts of sand and four parts of course gravel or crushed stone, to be thoroughly mixed, the top two inches of all work to be composed of one part of cement and three of sand, properly finished with a finishing tool made for that purpose. The whole of the work to be left clear and clean, and to the entire satisfaction of the Agent or Inspector in charge, and to be completed on or before the twenty ninth day of August, 1914.
A. E. HANNAH
